comment: I think the half smirk has to do with an attachment to trauma.  You may be recalling something you know was wrong, but there was some part of you or some part of the chaos that you enjoyed at the time, and it can be hard to separate the unhealthy behaviors from the sort of deviant attachment to it. That's why it isn't a genuine smile, because you don't want anyone to know that you not only tolerated the behaviours, but that some part of you has an almost fond attachment to it. I could definitely see this being a trait moreso in men as well because of the stigma attached to domestic abuse perpetrated by a woman. The smile could be a knee jerk reaction to not wanting to seriously discuss the abuse since it could be portrayed as unmasculine, or it could be a recall to happier times of her acting wild in a way that wasn't negatively directed at him. In any case, I think it's more akin to a nervous twitch than a sign of deception.

author: Sharon Dunbar

comment:
she's one of the reasons why I'm on the fence about the whole "always believe the victims first" of course it's different if it's anyone close to me because I'm right there with them and personally know them however, this thing on the internet where complete strangers would do anything to destroy your reputation over an accusation just doesn't sit right with me. And when new information comes out and turns out this "victim" was lying, no one wants to apologize and for some, it's just an "oh well" meanwhile, the person whose reputation and livelihood was heavily affected because of the accusation is left to pick up the pieces by themselves. Just because someone's rich or famous, or a man, doesn't mean it's any less difficult to get back up on their feet. There's always trauma in there especially when millions of people have demonized you without even blinking.

I can sympathize with a victim no problem. I just wouldn't immediately form opinions (strong ones at that) about an accusation without hearing the whole story.

comment:
As someone who makes that same face as Johnny when talking about the assault I suffered or various traumas I experienced in my life; I can say I 100% believe he was abused from watching this....No Doubts About It.

What hes doing I call a 'Sad Half Smile'. Its basically a reflexive half smile that you do when youre remembering something bad/sad but you wanna not become depressed by it or bring the listener down by it so youre trying to keep a Positive vibe....Well....some how your face just makes a Half Smile as if your brain is trying to FORCE you to be happy but because of your sad emotional state it only Half takes.

Its almost the same situation as Nervous Laughter.
Thats a situation where someone is Highly Uncomfortable but theyll Laugh Or Giggle.
Basically from what my Therapist told me when I asked her about the Sad Half Smile because it legit freaked me out at first she said "It is literally like a case of your Brain and your Body having a disconnect of sorts brought on by a stressful moment in time.
Your brain is trying to help you cope by making things lighter, but your body isnt fully invested in that notion so it only Half smiles." She said that in time as I become more able to cope and process sharing my story itll likely lessen. And for the most part its not as bad as it was.

Though when I do a LONG life story with people I have it happen ALOT because Ive had MANY sad things happen in my life and my heart sometimes feels like crying but my Brain is like "Keep It Together People Are Here No One Wants To See You Ballin' Your Eyes Out." SO....What comes out is that same exact half sad smile that Johnny does....
And knowing that I know what that look means makes it all the more sad listening to him and it makes me love him as a person even more.

Hes 100% gonna always be my Favorite Actor and I hope when Karma comes back to Bite Amber in the azz for what she did to him....I Hope It Bites HARD.
Cause she deserves to lose everything, Not Johnny.

author: Garcia MC

comment:
21:35 The half smile he gives is a sign of relief of finally being listened to and believed. The weight being lifted off of his shoulders and coming out of the darkness is bringing him joy and relief. He is choosing his words very carefully as this holds a lot of emotional weight for him, as apposed to AH who couldn't be bothered to make eye contact or even pretend to have a shred of interest even when it's made it to trial. She's likely spent so much of her life getting away with things by manipulating people that her humanity has withered away with apathy to the point she can't even be bothered to pretend she cares.

As men we tend to put on a brave face, but when we finally break down, we choke on our own words as we fight back the nearly impossible urge to cry. You can see in his eyes that he's been holding onto to this too long and it's broken him. Each time he's saying the words he scoffs or gives a faint chuckle, it's because after years of dismissing or justifying each individual incident and separating them mentally, now that they've all been laid together in front of him, even he can't really believe what he's saying, as he realizes how ridiculous it all sounds out loud, when up until now it's all been an internal monologue, how he's come to realize that he's been abused and manipulated and should have sought intervention a long time ago.

I've never been in his situation, but years ago I had met my "one" and when things didn't work out I ran myself through the ringer for years after, even years after not seeing her, I was remembering it all about a week ago and tried to admit to myself out loud the words "Because I was afraid I would never see her again" and got choked up as I was saying it that I couldn't get the last of it out, I ground to a halt and let out a smirk like Johnny did, I didn't think it was funny, I was internally admonishing myself for my emotional weakness in the face of a truth I was finally ready to admit.

comment:
From the first clip, we also see her recall.  It's left.  Not up and left, just left.

If the stats haven't shifted from years ago when I read them, most people recall with left and up.  Creating a scenario usually is the opposite, such as right and down.  This isn't EVERYONE, which is why this Base Line MUST MUST MUST MUST be established to read some one.

I see so many people try to 'Body Read' without having a Base Line on the subject.  Doesn't work.  All they're doing is assuming the individual to be a statistical 'average'.  You aren't reading the person then, you're just reading a text book and applying that to the individual instead.

So I was VERY happy to see him gathering a baseline here.

comment: To be honest, I am biased,  as I have had a crush on Johnny Depp since I first saw him as a teenager (so roughly half my life) and he has never disappointed. Truth be told, his seemingly sweet nature, his gentle demeanor and his soft-spoken approach are WHY I have had this ever-lasting crush. As that is the case for me, I cannot possibly imagine someone like that ever being physically abusive. I had a dream as a 15 year old in which Johnny told me "You should never let yourself be someone's trash can." I feel so strongly for this person who has always come across to me as a gentle person, that when he is being faced with the reality that the person he loved became so abusive, it hurts him. I see the pain in that half-smile, almost as if he doesn't want to believe it, doesn't want to think something so negative about someone so important and special in his life. This is NOT the attitude of someone who is angry at another. This is someone who cares and is hurt, distressed, upset. Contrast that with Amber's testimonial, in which she goes back and forth between seeming bored or uncomfortable, and being varying levels of defensive (even raising her voice and leaning forward pointedly). It's so clear to me that Johnny Depp is the person I have always seen him as, not some abusive monster who would push someone down a flight of stairs without a thought... at the risk of sounding like a Beatles-struck school girl, I love you Johnny. You are a beacon of light for many, many thousands of people and we all love you. You are not alone, and you are allowed to be strong. We have your back. <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 Bless him.

comment:
Hi.  I was just sitting here, hating Amber Heard with the intensity of a thousand suns, when I noticed various clips of her doing the whole movie promo interviews, and talking during interviews, and either she's the worst actress on the planet, or she genuinely has zero fucks to give that anyone can tell at a glance she harbors nothing but contempt for you, and she will have forgotten about you completely about 3 minutes before the interview ends.  Seriously, I haven't seen anything like it since Chevy Chase was still doing the talk show circuit.  I know you only interpret body language, but after being married to a certified sociopath for 10 soul-crushing years, I've become really good at spotting them. I've wished this series was around when I kept confronting my husband about blatant, obvious lies, only to have him turn it around on me every time as being wrong, and not understanding that letter he wrote to his friend about how, now he's married, he badly he wanted to fuck this woman he was "just friends with."  Apparently I read it completely wrong and it said nothing of the sort.  Like Amber Heard's performance telling people she donated 7 million dollars to the ACLU and the LA Children's hospital, and that she "wanted nothing for myself."  There's still some gold to be mined in that psychopath that suddenly has a baby as a prop to try to make the world hate her less.

Now, if only I could find a channel to describe what kind of person would defecate on their marriage bed, and proudly tell people about this act of revenge for Johnny showing up several minutes late for her 30th birthday party.  That is a whole other kind of sick.  Maybe Dr. Grande?

comment: I read her reactions as her feeling very uncomfortable with being asked questions that she did not want to answer truthfully;  many instances were not mentioned in this video that indicated that she either was about to deliver what she knew to be a lie or had just told a lie and instinctively followed it with forming a defensive barrier using her hand(s) / arm(s) - a few examples being 12:48 - having concluded answering the question, she could not contain showing a micro-aggression and her contempt for being questioned, by way of trying to bat away the person and question before her, and symbolically dismissing the person that had asked her the unwelcome question;  13:44 - her mouth grimace, indicating her discomfort from knowingly having told a lie;  14:15 - her placement of her hand to give her a small amount of soothing-self-comfort whilst more importantly her arm forms a defensive barrier between herself and her nemesis, created no doubt because she realised that her answer was too absurd to quash the question that had been asked.  As for JD, I suspect that he has long been  guilty of hiding the fact that he was a victim of domestic abuse and violence; and that when publicly questioned about such, that he still held back from fully revealing the traumas that he suffered. Furthermore, -15:27 - did you notice that Amber mocks the use of the verbs  used to describe her physical attack(s) ... and in doing so is reluctant to label such as a punch, hit or strike, opting to refer to one such attack as trying to 'push'' - which is a typical response by domestic abusers, to downplay the abuse that they commited and in doing so, often as not, to also mock the victim (which Amber did when she made the accusation 'whenever he was INJURED or touched it was always referred to in these ways of PUNCHING or OCKED or WHATEVER!' at this point she frantically delivers a lot of dismissive hand gesturing.

comment:
I will stake my own life on this statement...
That lady Amber is a bonafide sociopath, through & through. Everything I've seen and heard about her, which I've now sat and watched hours of today , I've seen a mirror likeness of before. She is cold, calculating, methodical! Bitterness & resentment governs her every action and emotion. 
Johnny Depp was/IS in the fight of his life to escape her clutches, and I FULLY BELIEVE one of the comments he made, when he said, "He was scared to death and didn't know what to do." He said it because he realized he fell in love with pure evil and the only escape he had would be a never ending nightmare, which he's been living now for years!! He knew it, and I assure you, he foresaw the outcome he now fights with. 
We have not heard the last of Amber Heard. If we could ever a fly on the wall, or secretly record what her own sister has to say about her, THAT is where we'd find the real truth. Her family knows what she is and what she's capable of, but say nothing b/c they are trapped in her web too! I again stake my life on that fact!
Here is the absolute truth about what happens when your sociopath partner knows you've figured them out... YOU BECOME THEIR PUREST ENEMY & NOTHING IS HELD BACK FOR THEM TO DESTROY EVERYTHING THEY CAN ABOUT YOU! And I mean everything. 
Lucky for Johnny it only took him a year of marriage to figure it out, and get the fock out! I bet he knows he'll be picking up the pieces of this unholy terror, for a long long time to come!

comment:
Why is she eating?
They aren't sustainable, they are snacks foods 

Eating, especially bite sized foods with specific textures is associated with self soothing. The motions of eating and chewing and the satisfaction of the texture in the mouth is, on a base level, soothing. Eating feels good. The stomach is the second source of serotonin in the body. It is a self soothing action to eat under stress

comment:
As a professional, you should use proper grammar. Regards is something you use to give best wishes. For instance at the end of a letter. Best regards, and your name.

If this is your career, use proper grammar.

comment: I couldn't even get through this because it was SO DISGUSTING. You ought to be ASHAMED for what you're doing to victims of violence. Your so-called "expertise" was clearly biased and not even completely focused on body language!  You make a lot of wild assumptions and draw a lot of conclusions based on bullshit like "HOW COULD SHE EAT??" FYI, as a lawyer, I can tell you straight up that people eat in depositions because they're LONG AS FUCK.  And no shit she didn't want to be there!!! Her husband sued her for libel and she has to sit in a long as fuck deposition recounting every piece of crap that she ever said or did that could possibly be construed against her.  If you consider her perspective at all (which you clearly don't), you'd understand that after you've been abused for a long period of time, and justifying someone's horrible behavior towards you, you'd be *absolutely pissed* if the person who did that to you dragged you back to court to prove you're a liar.  And being that the guy she did that is a massive celebrity, I can't even imagine how much hate she endured up to that point.   And people like you and all the idiots on the internet will buy into it because it's easy to buy into the stereotype that women are manipulative evil liars. Literally, people like you are the reason that women don't report abuse. FUCK YOU.

comment: Only half way through and had to stop as there are so many problems with your analysis. I have no particular care for Amber Herd and don‚Äôt have an opinion on whether she was the victim or perpetrator so this comment is not a defence of her, it‚Äôs merely to point out your inaccuracies. The very first one (which didn‚Äôt bode well for the rest of the video) was when she nodded yes but said no right at the start. That happened because she was nodding yes to the question ‚Äúdo you understand?‚Äù while answering no to the question ‚Äúdid you hit Johnny?‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt say anything about her own disbelief in her answer. Then you speak about her self-soothing actions as soon as she answers an uncomfortable question. That happens when she is describing a situation of violence toward herself. It is common for victims to self sooth and shake their heads when recalling abuse they suffered. Your response to her eating is oddly passionate, perhaps making it the strongest indicator of your bias. She would have needed permission to have food in a trial in the first place so whatever the reason she needs to eat during the trial, that reason was obviously acceptable to the court. It‚Äôs not something she‚Äôd just randomly do. In fact, the first time she puts food in her mouth she looks off to the corner as if to confirm it‚Äôs ok. Your problem with her babbled response to the question about the audio of her apology is unfounded as it is exactly the type of response you should expect from someone who feels they‚Äôre being led into a verbal trap with a piece of evidence taken out of context. It‚Äôs clear that the audio evidence is to point out that Amber must have hit him otherwise she wouldn‚Äôt be apologising for it and her response indicates she knows that‚Äôs what they‚Äôre trying to imply. It‚Äôs incredibly common for abuse victims to apologise to perpetrators later when the perpetrator accuses the victim of hurting them during their own attack. Again, I don‚Äôt necessarily think Amber is the victim in this case, I‚Äôm just pointing out that your analysis takes none of that into account. Finally, you keep talking about her nonchalance as if it points to her guilt when in fact it could just as easily do the opposite. When someone who has been traumatised is trying to deal with a situation of reliving the trauma without getting emotional, one way to do that is disassociate as if the entire situation doesn‚Äôt matter. However, in this case I get the impression her nonchalant behaviour is purposeful to express the fact she doesn‚Äôt think she should be there at all, which any victim would feel if they were being questioned as if they were the perpetrator. AGAIN not saying that‚Äôs my personal belief, just that it‚Äôs a reading of the situation you‚Äôve completely missed. I‚Äôm not sure if you‚Äôre reading this unfavourably because of your own opinion against Amber Herd or because you know popular opinion sways toward Johnny Depp but the one thing that I am sure of is that no one should rely on your body language analyses.

comment:
I don't know nor do I care if she's guilty, but, this body language reading is bullsh*t and/or sloppy: 
 
The nodding and saying no: She nods to say/show that she understands the question, and says "no" as an answer to the question it self at the same time. It's so obvious that I can't believe no-one else points it out. It's not weird or confused. 
 
The "duh"-behaviour is obvious to me: she's been asked the same thing a thousand times. Although not smart behaviour, it's not strange considering. 
 
The obsessive eating might seem strange, but it could be comfort-/nervous eating, not strange at all to me - but strange that it's allowed in court. If someone gave her snacks as a possibility to think answers through it's even weirder, BUT comparing being able to talk with a small piece in her mouth (which she had no problem with) and a LARGE piece (which might seem rude) is just silly. You can see the size difference of the pieces. But yes, it seems to be a concious decicion to eat a large piece at that exact moment, I agree with that.

I've heard that I have defensive body language, when I'm just holding my arms confortably, and have many examples of body language analysis that is 100% wrong. In the beginning of the video you're saying it's not a science and at best 70% accurate, but still you sound so sure when you deliver some of these analytical comments, which makes me not trust this at all.

comment: I still support Depp and believe Heard to be a narcissist... but when alcohol and drugs are involved, it's very difficult to get to the truth.  Most people who know me will know me as a peace-loving, gentle, mild-mannered and generous person.  I've been told this countless times. And I like to think it's true.  When I'm sober, it's true.  But when I've been drunk in the past - and especially to the point of blackout - a different person has come out. Violent, abusive, physically destructive (even if I've never hit another person in my life).  I've been arrested and Sectioned for criminal damage and social disturbance.  All of these things have happened (including suicide attempts) during periods of extreme emotional stress - and most often they've been connected to emotional relationships (especially my last relationship, which was with - wouldn't you know - a narcissist).  Sober, I can look at these things and shake my head in despair and disbelief, as well as guilt and deep remorse for the hurt I've caused other people.  But that's what alcohol and drugs can do.  When I say they make me into a different person, I should qualify:  the person they turn me into is still me; the Dr Jekyll side of me.  The dark side that sobriety manages to control.  The id of me comes out.  I'm not proud of that side of me.  That's why I'm still on Johnny Depp's side over all of this.  I believe he is gentle, peace-loving and generous - but that adverse emotional circumstances with a dangerous and manipulative narcissist, coupled with alcohol, could easily have pushed him over the edge.  I hope he manages to recover his career and his well-being.  As for Heard... I wish she could be neither seen nor heard!  I should add, as a person with late-diagnosed Asperger Syndrome, that I find all of this body language stuff fascinating and revealing.  I wouldn't have picked up a single one of those cues without them being explained to me.

comment:
When reading body language one must consider the person's age, upbringing, culture, idiosyncrasies, current mental state, or if they have a disorder. For example, in Hispanic culture, it is expected for a person being reprimanded to look down in shame when being corrected. I believe this is also true in several Asian cultures.¬† However, in American culture it is expected for a person being reprimanded to look their superior in the eyes to show that they are paying attention and show respect. 

Another example is that pointing with their index finger is considered very offensive in certain cultures. So most Americans wouldn't think much of a foreign person pointing with their index finger. However, if you consider that in their culture, that gesture is considered an offense, the meaning changes substantially.¬† 

Also, woman in many foreign cultures are expected to be meek and show as little expression/emotion as possible. Some cultures have that whole "women should be seen and not heard" mentality. This would affect how women of these culture express body language, or lack thereof. 

Similarly,¬† many (but not all) autistic people show little to no emotion in  their body language and/or verbal expressions. Many avoid eye contact. Many speak in a monotone emotionless voice while also not displaying any apparent body language. Other disorders/diseases may cause misread body language as well, such as Tourettes syndrome, ataxia, dystonia, Parkinson, etc.

dude, the looking around can also be a sign of discomfort for any other reason, not only the suggestive ones you mentioned, so yeah she doesn't wanna be there. And she nodded as a response of "ye sure, I'm listening, I know what you are saying" and said ""no" as the answer to the question that was told aloud twice about the dv. So yes - two distant communication devices - two different questions one of which she is answering with yes and one of which she is answering with no. 

"wow its interesting, now she doesnt talk with her mouth full" - its not interesting, she just took a bigger chunk of that food. She faked it after a moment, which you did not comment. That is more intresting.

comment:
He didn't communicate anything leading up to her bottle throwing. At least not with what you've shown us. And, since the truth often lies in-between, I'd bet that after she threw the bottle, he chased her down, leading to the struggle with the door. I was born into this shit. Molded by it. 
Johnny Depp is intelligent. You can see it. He has influence and power. He has experience, and he's a very talented actor. To engage in conflict with him would be a mental game for sure. 
Amber doesn't seem as calculating as he does. I honestly don't think she's that smart, and she's obviously not as good an actor as he is. She doesn't have the influence or power either. And, he's a man, so he's physically stronger than she is. 
I don't think every aggression she ever committed was justified, and that's why she has a hard time defending herself. But they become more understandable if you consider the toxicity she was quite possibly enduring for an extended period of time. 
Obviously, I could be wrong. But something seems off about how eager everyone is to paint her as the abuser, when none of us really knows for sure.

author: Mira M. S.

comment: I and my partners are abuse survivors. We do that smile - that *exact* smile - when reflecting on or recalling/relaying incidents of abuse or information about our abusers. It's not unlike how people might laugh when they're terrified. In our cases, it can be anything from protecting ourselves from going back to that moment to feeling contempt toward ourselves and/or our abusers. A lot of the time, it's the latter. I think this is, like in many other half-smile/smirk observations, this is contempt. The more symmetrical smile was desperation escapism, trying to get away from the pain and fear caused by the abuse.

comment:
The fact is that society needs to change a lot even to this day. Many good men and women aren't violent because of who they are, when you add an abuser to either of their lives it can make physical and mental obstacles or trauma. Which then can create triggers that other rude or violent people can tap into... I myself even get nervous / triggered when toxic people (violent, alcoholic etc.) argue or fight with other people that don't even concern me because it's putting myself in between a rock and a hard place. For example, either I stop the women / man being beaten up by her / his partner which puts me in a lot of danger... or I don't do anything until police prescience is needed. Then again involving myself in general could get myself in deep trouble depending on who I confront / call the cops on. 

We all have struggles as either gender but at in the same light have many similar struggles... and sometimes emotions can hurt a hell of a lot more than physical abuse!
The only thing I can say to help at this moment is that women should be more careful and analytical as most of the time they're weaker physically which can get them in even more dangerous situations. Same with weaker men, think really hard about intervening etc! We all can be broken mentally but try to build a strong mind through self analytical measures & knowledge, if we all change our-selves to be better we'll slowly improve society, halting some of those potential toxic people which usually create more toxic people (similar to a pandemic).

comment: Does anyone pay attention to the symmetry between left and right eye lid openness, and left versus right side of mouth openness symmetry?  I am pretty ignorant of body language analysis versus truth telling, but I do intuitively use left right symmetry of eye lids and mouth.  My theory is that the left side of the face is more open when the right side of the brain is dominating communication, and the right side is more open when the language center of the left side of the brain is dominating; the language center takes over when using words to lie.  The right side of the brain closes down the left side of the face when it does not agree with what the language center on the left side of the brain is communicating.  And conversely, the right side of the face closes down when the left side of the brain is trying to hold back truthful communications that it does not want released.  Amber is tough to read with eye and mouth symmetry; she is very symmetrical throughout this video.  The only time her left side is more open is when she is talking about defending her sister, which in my analysis means she is relating some episode in her life when she defended her sister.  Also, anger slips through during this answer which could be intentional acting, though she does not seem to be that good an actor.  In the Johnny Depp segment his left eye lid is consistently more open and, other than a few smirks he talks out of the left side of his mouth.

comment: I am (unfortunately) related to someone who is a textbook narcissist, meaning they don‚Äôt recognize themselves as one and are constantly shifting blame to other persons they have relations with by means of lying and purposefully inciting other people to anger with their actions and words and then playing the victim.  They also go to a (obviously mediocre) therapist to complain about the people they abuse in a sad attempt to get sympathy instead of actually addressing their deep rooted flaws and destructive behavior.  Bad actors, unprofessional medical personnel and people abusing positions of power to threaten and commit unethical acts are far too common in our supposedly advanced and modern culture in which virtually every participant lacks either the ability or the say so to hold one another accountable.  Yes, we all have flaws, some are just not as heinous as others.  It often feels like a fight for a cause that can never be won.  Here‚Äôs to hoping the world can change, one (mostly) good person at a time. Everything has an expiration date, including this planet.  Let‚Äôs try to preserve it a little longer by striving to be better to ourselves and everything around us. My diatribe might be lame, but I do really, truly care.

comment: I keep saying this on videos about Amber Heard but I was married to somebody just like her and it was and still is awful. What I hear Johnny talk about having bottles thrown at him think about my ex-wife picking up the bag potatoes and hitting me with it a bunch of times or how she tore our marriage certificate within a week of our being married even though we're married for another 20 years we never had the original marriage certificate. I can think of the time she threw a crystal bowl  into my face. I can think of numerous times she punched me to square in the face. One time she dislocated my jaw and it's one of her proudest moments. She tells the kids about how she made my jaw hurt for a month. If there is people around she would literally take me around a corner to hit me and tell me how stupid I was before we went back to company. And during our marriage all she did was sleep and leave with her friends leaving me to do all the childcare whenever I wasn't working. And by the way she never worked. But I guarantee you if we went to court she would have a narrative where I was the scary guy and she was the victim. I'm a big dude. People have a hard time looking at me and seeing somebody who wad pushed around for 20 years. There is one time early in our marriage when I wanted to leave her and I was collecting some stuff and trying to leave with my mother. My mother was in her car waiting for me and I was taking some stuff out to her car and my ex came up behind me and started tearing at my clothes and grabbing at my hair and clawing at me and I was just trying to get to the car my hands are full of stuff and I didn't even have the ability to grab her because of what was in my hands but she was clawing at me and grabbing at me in the whole time screaming for help. She was actually screaming for me to let go of her. I had a box in my hands she had my hair in her hands and she was screaming for anybody in the distance to make it seem like I was assaulting her. If something would have happened and her neighbor would have called the police reporting that they heard a woman screaming for help they would have put my giant ass in jail and I'd still be dealing with an assault charge that she would probably treat like it was a real assault against her. She's kicked me and my children out of the house forcing us to stay in our car overnight because we disagreed with her. But if we're in court she would say she kicked me out because she was scared for her safety. I can't imagine how she would reason that should take the kids out to or how she would explain why they stood up for me , which is why she kicked them out with me. I have a lot to contend with and I'm going to go through the wringer just like Johnny Depp and I don't have money for lawyer. comment:
The judge ruled Johnny Depp assaulted Amber Heard on 12 different occasions and put her in actual fear for her very life on 3 different occasions. In a court of law he IS considered a wife beater and the Sun is perfectly in the right to call him so. 

Our dude is greasy. He needs to take a gd shower and go to rehab before he dies from $30k a month worth of wine, pills, ecstacy and cocaine. He "seems awkward in public" because he's intoxicated. Drugged and drunk to the very extent to which the human body can withstand. You'd be awkward too if you had, "been awake 3 days snorting powder, pills, wine, 2 bottles of champers on the plane..", probably the same plane he admits to attempting to "playfully tap" kick Amber on the ass during an argument as she was walking away. 

Can you imagine if your husband tried to kick you during an argument as you were walking away?! The witnesses to the event said that Amber continued to walk off crying. If that was me I would have wrecked that entire plane into the ground to get to his wasted ass if my husband was as disrespctful of me, his life partner, as JD was of his wife and life partner, AH. 

All these JD ass kissing videos with lies about amber and the case clickbait that I've watched never bring up the fact that Amber only started recording the things he did because the next day when she had to tell him what he did and said and how much it sucked for her when he was black out wasted, he couldn't remember anything! 

There's probably a reason JD couldn't get Vanessa to marry him. He's a disaster, a walking drug overdose. The last person that can be a good husband. Ladies that have been in a marriage with someone that was constantly drunk and drugged, was it a decent marriage? Was he a decent, competent husband or was he very sick, toxic to his marriage and to you, and need psychiatric care? Did you feel more like a babysitter than a wife? JD needs to go straight from the courtroom to his room in a rehab in my opinion, and I'm sure many psychiatrist's opinions are well.

Smfh...."$30k a month on 'wine'". Btw, to deny to himself how big a problem he has, he claims the wines he buys are "investments". His accountants counter that, "it's not an investment if you drink it as soon as you buy it." ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è He's really gone downhill. I know he was always a drug addict and an alcoholic, but now that he's 60 it's really starting to show. I don't think he's gonna live much longer abusing drugs and alcohol to the extent he does...he's pushing 60 partying like a 24 year old. 

Shame. HUGE shame, he is one of my favorite actors and I don't believe in enabling and letting people remain in denial about their substance abuse disorder until it kills them. Why doesn't Vanessa and or his daughter and son stage an intervention for their Father, or the father of their children??! Will he rough them up too if they said something like what he did to A when she tried to intervene? Ignoring this will not make this go away, but it will make him go away. Forever. This is how people die. He needs to address this issue. His family needs to take him for a 9 month in patient stay at Betty Ford. No more going to the Bahamas to his private island to "dry out" he needs to be in an actual rehab that uses intensive therapy all day and mental health medication, therefore he has to have doctors and he needs to stay inpatient for at least 6 to 9 months. No jumping over the fence after less than a day and going home and doing an huge shot to the arm and then a shot in the head like kurt. We've seen this happen to all of our heroes. We cant let it happen AGAIN to JD!

comment:
I had a (semi-serious) altercation with a boyfriend that I was trying to evict from my apartment.  The whole thing will sound stupid (because that's what it was)....
He had moved into my place.  Within 6 months, he was reneging on his rent/food/loan payments (for a boat that we were "sharing"), and I had asked him several times to move out.  One night, we were over-served on wine when the topic came up again.  Tempers flared.  Other than the arguing, details are scrambled.  At some point, he had me pressed against a wall, with his hands around my throat.  I don't believe that I was actually frightened at any point, but I was certainly angry about his mistreatment.  I can certainly understand that trying to tell the story in court would be difficult.
From Johnny's statements, a great deal of alcohol was involved.

comment: I work within the Domestic Abuse arena, and I found this very difficult to comprehend. DA is horrendous, and no victim would willingly re-live the abuse, especially in a stressful situation such as court hearings. A lot of abuse victims will minimise what happened, and wherever the "power" within the relationship lays, a victim will NOT want to cause further problems for themselves. Viewing this, I'm sad to say I do not view AH as a true victim, and it appears that JD is the one minimising. That's not to say this is not an abusive relationship, but I really don't think the full facts have been laid out. I hope they are both able to move on and have healthier relationships in the future

For instance, at the beginning she ‚Äúis insecure‚Ä¶ does blocking gestures‚Äù in her answer regarding not domestically abusing Johnny Depp. I feel she ‚Äúacted‚Äù like a victim. A victim does feel insecure and blocks when verbally questioned. Not that i believe she is a true victim. I definitely feel this is disingenuous, and is a studied act. Another thing about depositions i have to say- the other side cuts you off and doesn‚Äôt listen which is very frustrating- a lot of people then look like they don‚Äôt want to be there (look bored) and do self soothing gestures. comment: I bet this scene in this movie caused them to scrap the whole project! She is definitely the worst actress in the world. What kind of moron would ever take her seriously! Anytime someone is speaking in present tense as they are describing the story and pausing for several seconds at a time the story is being created at that particular Moment In Time. At any time someone witnessed an event, a truthful person speaks in past tense. If someone is speaking in present tense of an event that happened previously, it is only natural for them to speak in past tense! Besides all that what kind of ignorant buffoon would be stuffing her ugly face being fully cognizant of a conversation involving them? Never in my 58 years of being on this planet have I ever witnessed anyone not even a four-year-old child stuffing their face when being spoken to! Is it not customary for humans to stuff their face while seated at a table with a napkin on their lamp with a spoon or fork in their hand While others are also participating in the same activity? Even animals only eat while others are eating with them. At one time I used to respect to Johnny Depp but after seeing this debauchery I refuse to allow my boyfriend to dress up like him next Halloween!

comment:
Hey dude, I think you're kinda wrong about her. Seems like you're just judging her for how she's reacting, in a lawyer way, you know? Not properly analyzing but kinda fishing for what you want. 
Watching specifically to see if she's guilty or innocent, interrupts your ability to evaluate why she may have reacted in that way in the first place and begins to incorrectly paint a picture that matches some narrative. Your personal frustrations and misunderstanding of the situation lead to false assumptions, opinions, and accusations as to why she's behaving or responding in a certain way. 
For example; you ask, "Why is she so uninterested in being here if she's the victim?" Well, I'd say it's because they're trying to paint her like she's not a victim and actually the monster. Which then makes perfect sense to me why she would be reacting that way, and honestly baffles me how you find it confusing. But then I remember, you're not properly analyzing. You believe she's guilty and are trying to prove yourself right.  Lawyers are always trying to play some sorta 'HA GOT YA' game and it's very tiring and that's the main thing I'm seeing from her. She doesn't wanna be there for sure.

comment:
So, i accidentally ended up on this video this morning on my hour long commute. 
As a genuine DV survivor I can sincerely say this video made me shake with anger toward her. Its women like this that are the reason actual victims are ignored. Like Jody Arias (sp?) Its all fabricated,  and a pathetic attempt at attention and fame. Neither of these women are genuine victims of long term DV. Shes up there talking about.            " escaping", yeah.... no. None of this pans out. Theres no way she'd try "escaping" with her abuser actively pursuing her. Thats called engaging . None of Her behavior is reasonable.  She shows zero fear, zero shame (which whether or not we deserve it, there's ALWAYS shame) . This is really disgusting. YEARS later I still couldn't portray this much apathy IF I TRIED when discussing the abuse. 
Ok, some say that everyone is different and processes differently but there are universal behaviors.  She shows none.  . . Anyway, thats my TED talk. 
Grrrrrrrr....

comment:
"A complete science like something like psychology is..."

LOLwut? Psychology has a long history of unfalsifiable hypotheses and confirmation bias. Dianetics had a lot of support in the psychology community in the 50s. Transactional analysis still has a lot of adherents despite the utter lack of any demonstrable physiological basis for the PAC model. Today, the area of gender dysphoria, particularly atypical presentations and treatment recommendations, is more influenced by politics and ideology, rather than empirical concerns.

It's scarcely more scientific than something like astrology...

comment:
I agree with the bulk of your analysis, but at 5:15 when she nods while saying "no"... she was asked first "did you hit Depp?" and then before she answers "do you understand the question?". She's obviously nodding in affirmation that she understands the question while her saying "no" is obviously her answer to the first question. I have no idea why you'd class this as a strong "non verbal misalignment".

I would suggest that this is a case, on your part, that you can't see the forest for the trees. i.e. maybe you're so focused on her body language that you've ignored, or forgotten, the context.

comment:
The whole point of communication is delivering ideas. Humans do it through two channels, verbal and non-verbal. We have a lot more conscious control over the verbal channel. Lying then is interesting to watch. It is trying to force ideas through these two channels, but that non-verbal channel is so much harder to consciously control. It makes lying (usually) see a disconnect between those two channels because they are in conflict. 

I don't know the full situation between these two but it is plainly clear who has less conflict between those two channels. I know nothing of Heard, but just looking at this short clip, her communication seems very forced which is strange; if she was being honest, she wouldn't have to force her communication. It would come without effort. Why is there so much apparent force being used to communicate if what she is saying is authentic and sincere?

author: Even Bet

comment:
I actually came here to watch this with a very open mind. But I am only 5min in, and can already detect bias in _your_ behaviour and expressions. That "Oh my god" you blurt out after you first hear her speak in the clip (5:19). Then right after you list things that could explain why she doesn't want to be there (5:23). You say boredom, guilt, or she doesn't want to be caught. How about listing 'innocence' as a possible reason for not wanting to be part of this interview...?!
I have no opinion in this case either way, and personally believe that both probably carry a bit of guilt. But when I watch an analysis on YT, I expect the person doing it to be impartial. And not show after five minutes that he's already picked sides.

Edit: 5:57 It's not really a misalignment. She nods 'yes' to the person indicating she understands what the interviewer is asking. She says 'no' as an answer to the initial question (whether she was violent). The interviewer asked two questions after another, so it's not Amber being misaligned, it's actually poor questioning of the interviewer. Watch it again: 4:59

7:30 Omg, and in the next part you are criticising her for shaking her head, although this time that is aligned with her 'no' answer. So, it's pretty clear that either way she does it, you criticise it... That's enough for me to think you have no idea what you are talking about and try to find things to criticise about her. You are clearly not unbiased, so I personally won't watch the rest of your clip, and will see whether there is a more impartial analysis out there.

Last thing I will say is, her being innocent and being asked again and again whether she engaged in domestic violence by various people, would equally explain shrugging and blocking gestures and her not wanting to be there, especially if you feel that your interviewer (and half the world) is already biased like in this case. (You are also a great case in point for that.) This "analysis" is laughable.

author: Traci Nixon

comment:
As a man that was in an abusive relationship with a female I can kind of explain Johnny Depp's seeming half smirk possibly. Assuming Johnny Depp is a victim of abuse himself which I do not presume to know the answer to... Men are generally held to a certain standard socially. Women are as well and they have to deal with their own negative and unfair social pressures. For men it is this perception that you have to be tough, calm, and you can never be a victim. This obviously is not true across the board for all men just as assumptions about women are not always true. But it is something most men deal with growing up, and only marginally gets lessened with age. Depp is recalling what he claims to be a traumatic experience of being victimized by an abusive woman. if it is true his smirk is his male ego deflecting the severity of the attack in order to preserve his masculinity. It is in general unintentional. It took me a long time to be able to admit my tiny ex fiance abused me. I make jokes or smirk when I talk about it sometimes as well, especially if I were forced to in a very public deposition. It is humiliating - men and women tend to respond to humiliation in different ways and to different things. To me there is nothing odd about that half smirk.

And to be fair and play devil's advocate Amber could be a victim of abuse. Her boredom could be explained by the fact she has had to explain this so many times, her lack of passion could be because she truly does not feel that passionate about it. Not everyone responds to abuse in the same way. But whether or not she is "passionate" about being victimized has no relevance. If Johnny Depp abused her she is not required to respond in any one way to it. Maybe she is a bit of a "tougher" person (using this language as delicately as possible to make a point) who often fought back against the abuse but never presented herself as a victim. Eventually one like that can come to terms with the fact they have been abused and had to be defensive so often against the abuser and is perhaps overly defensive when that abusers lawyers are grilling her? Maybe some things she struggles to recall clearly are because it was not that traumatizing to her and she simply forgot every occasion because there were so many? I really do not know but I do know not every victim is required to behave the same way or to accept that they are a victim in order for abuse to occur. Many people who grew up seeing abuse of some kind stay in abusive relationships because it seems normal to them and simply do not recognize it as abuse (even though it is)

Overall my opinion which does not matter at all because I do not know these people nor do I have any authority in the outcome, but I feel Johnny Depp is probably telling the truth. She seems deceitful to me. But I am a biased person who was in an abusive relationship before so I would not do well on this jury.
author: Jacob J. Oliver

comment: As a body language analyst do you have 'tells' to identify if someone is neurodiverse? Like, in Amber's case it's striking how she presents with quite a few mannerisms a person with a mental disorder would. For example, if she had ADHD or ASD, many of the things she does would make sense, even if she was, in fact, the victim. I'm not writing this in her defense, I do not know or care for her. However, I do care for the neurodivergent community and some bits of your video, unbeknownst to you, may be a bit offensive. Quite a few people do struggle with sensory issues, are stimulus seeking, need to self soothe, and have a poor working memory and executive function they may need to use strategies to compensate for. It would be great if some of these typically non-neurotypical tells were not straight off the bat associated with psychopathology... Similarly, people who have PTSD or have experienced trauma and are forced to recall may also act strange at face value. (To my knowledge it is the nature of trauma that memories of the event may get jumbled and mixed up. It's a cognitive defense mechanism.) I am not hinting you are mistaken. I am asking if you have ways to distinguish these different scenarios.

comment: I can honestly chime in, as someone who survived Childhood abuse... as others are thankfully also saying here in the comment section. The thing Johnny Depp does, where he smirks or tries to smile or even tries to laugh. When talking about these instances/memories. Is a very common thing, amongst people who have lived under/with abuse. Especially for such a long time that they've had to develop coping and self-soothing mechanism, just to withstand and accept it and their reality. While I have been free of the abuse for going on 10yrs now, and have been in and out of therapy, as well as a special type of therapy meant to help me be able to recall and remember past moments and instances of abuse, without total mental/emotional and physical breakdown... I still, to this day, do things like that. I'll smile or even laugh, when recalling or talking about past moments. I've been told by people that care about me, now. That they really don't know how to respond because they say it looks like I'm about to cry or breakdown, but I smile and laugh instead. It's literally a coping mechanism. Making light, or a very dark situation (for your sake and others) because the reality and truth of it is so heavy. So, I just wanted to say as someone who's also been abused, and not just physical abuse but mental and emotional as well... I know exactly what Johnny is doing, when he does that smirk, smile or laugh üòî

comment:
One note about the 'irrelevant' objection.

This is a deposition. The judge is not present to rule on objections; those will be argued later before the judge. Any objection to a question has to be recorded *during* the deposition, or else it's not timely and silence indicates acceptance of the question as valid.

So what many lawyers do in depositions -- particularly if they're in defensive mode -- is raise every objection they can imagine *might* be sustained, even if it's slim odds.

So what that objection is, is not the lawyer declaring that it's irrelevant so much as marking the issue for later argument, more or less on spec. The lawyer really, really REALLY wants questions in this particular area to be thrown out, so it's time to throw the kitchen sink.

comment: In her first explanation, she was trying to escape from a room where Johnny was attacking her, meaning Johnny was in the room with her.  She then exited the room through the door and then tried to close the door behind her but Johnny wasn't letting her close the door.  I can see that being a reasonable explanation.  But then in her follow-up answer she says Johnny was trying to get into the room that she was "trying to escape in".  I'm not sure what the phrase "trying to escape in" means.  Usually people say trying to escape from, meaning she was trying to leave that room, or trying to escape to, meaning she was trying to seek sanctuary in another room she wasn't currently in.  Either way it sure would be nice if she clarified which room she was in like the living room and what room was on the other side of the door, like the bathroom.

comment: I can't blame her at all for responding to the questions the way she did.  Why?  Because the questions seem to be somewhat antagonistic and accusatory.  They don't seem to be designed to give her a way to prove her innocence, but rather they seem to be designed to discover any wrongdoing on her part.  It seems like the questions are coming from someone from the other side of the fight - either a prosecutor or someone representing Johnny.  It's like they are trying to get her to trap herself with her answers, NOT like they are trying to give her a way to prove her innocence. If I were in her shoes, I would be frustrated at the person asking the questions, and have a bad attitude about having to answer them, whether I was guilty or not.

comment: So, her brows stay completely still. How is that important? When my grandpa was dying, he couldn't talk and his eyes were closed because he couldn't see. So I asked the nurse how they knew when someone was in pain when they couldn't communicate. She said they check brows. They check them being pushed together and the forehead and skin between brows crinkled. I'm now studying to be a social worker and we have to learn body language and a sure sign of a person in pain (even if mentally only) is the brows. A forensic body language specialist caught a murderer in British Columbia this way when he saw her interview on tv asking to please return her disappeared daughter. He called the cops saying her brows showed anger and frustration (going down, compared to pain going up). The police investigated her and turned out she murdered her daughter. - point being: with everything happening in that clip Amber's face only shows disinterest and her being annoyed. No pain retelling the story whatsoever. Johnny on the other hand, when he begins his brows are furrowed upward which shows it's painful to recall and when he tells of the bottle incident his forehead crinkles and his brows are expressive. She is lying through her teeth, and he's trying to stay strong.
author: Menke Meijer

comment: I'm no Amber Heard fan, but when she is nodding yes and then stating "no", it seems to me like she's merely misunderstanding a cue from her lawyer. In depositions like this, I know that lawyers will teach their client certain tells to respond to if they are asked a specific legal question that will have specific legal consequences...these can seem like questions with an obvious answer, but may actually have certain legal repercussions depending on the specifics of the case. Even if it is a simple question, I could easily - at least - see myself being so nervous about screwing up that I lose focus (maybe because I'm paying too much attention to how my lawyer is responding rather then what is being said).

comment: Also, when she first put the food in her mouth it was when she had to listen to the recordings. Who would want to be in court?? Who would want to listen to traumatic events, and relive them?? I can tell you I sure as shit would be looking like I didn‚Äôt want to fucking be there either. It‚Äôs not that difficult to put yourself in someone else‚Äôs shoes. And I‚Äôd pretty much give up if someone had already made up their minds and wouldn‚Äôt let me speak for up myself either. Depps attorney said what I asked was a yes or no question. Basically stupidly admitting  she was not interested in hearing Heard‚Äôs side of the story. She wanted her to say ‚Äúyes I hit him‚Äù so she could be like THERE IT IS I got her confession!! She got Heard fucked up. My abuser kept me sleep deprived (I am diagnosed with CFS) and was trying to record me without my consent and when I tried to answer his questions, he snapped at me angrily saying ‚ÄúI SAID YES OR NO QUESTIONS‚Äù and I of course kept pleading to go to bed. I knew what he was doing and I knew he and his whack job mother were trying to get me to say very specific things, to make me look abusive. I did everything I could to not have to answer him. Then when he was busy, I got the recordings from his phone and sent them to family to keep for me. I deleted them from both our phones. I also found evidence on his phone where his mother was coaching him on what to do and say to me. His sister was heavily involved as well. It was a terrible situation all around. I got messed up with the wrong family. A family of abusers. I met them at church. But my faith is unwavering.

comment: Mr Observe, please stop on this issue. You are way out of your depth, experience or expertise. What she just described I have heard over a thousand times. The other party will argue for days on end that even gently pushing them away was an act of violence. It is all about the wordplay for abusers. One man announced 'I never punched my wife!' No one said he had but he did snap her arm, tear out half of her hair in front of their 3 year old son, make his child watch as he strangled the mother on the floor etc. But, to him, only PUNCHING counted. And ANYTHING she did was 'She gave me an evil look.' 'I can't take her abusiveness any more.' That was when she tried to get away to a neighbour's house for safety with the two children. It's the calm. logical responses we are trained to prefer in society but this is used to manipulate everyone into buying his (or her) story and make a joke out of the victim's lack of composure or she used the wrong word ad nauseum. Try reading Dr Donn Hennessy's book on this. But stay in your own lane, whatever that is.
author: Tara Walsh-Arpaia

comment: She was deposed. She has no choice but to be there. One of the hardest things victims find is the constant repetition of every tiny detail over and over and over and over etc. That is either when they give up or have good support. Most are, by definition, isolated and so that support is not there unless via an agency.
author: Tara Walsh-Arpaia

comment: This man has No qualification in complex traumatic reactions (often dissociated and/or seemingly detached (bored or uninterested). Read any book on this. It won't take long to find this. Recall the days in earlier eras where the police did not believe rape victims because they weren't screaming and rolling all over the floor bur seemed dissociated and even calm or bored. That is the traumatic reaction in a nutshell. Domestic abuse victims are so accustomed to being ridiculed and gaslighted that they do come across as confused and tentative when telling their stories because their bodies are still reacting to the complex trauma reaction.
author: Tara Walsh-Arpaia

comment: Well, I am off this guy (and the whole fake field he is in). I am a lawyer and a Dr of Psychology and have devoted a great deal of my professional life to working with domestic abuse cases. First off, I have never seen a victim 'allow themselves to crack' emotionally while being deposed. It is a hostile environment and these individuals are generally extremely jumpy, nervous and desperately trying to appear normal and composed (even if we think they fail in a normal context). The abuse is emotional in every event and has an enormous emotionally traumatic, even dissociative, effect on the victims. What this man sees as not taking the situation seriously, we call dissociating because it is the best they can do. See comment below from a victim. The problem is that, in Court or in the legal context, crying etc is, to be blunt, going to irritate the judge and other lawyers and become more hostile toward the testifying victim. The best ones are so lost in a hardened shell in which they have had to live, mostly for their children's sakes. The moment they crack, not in Court or while being deposed, they can begin to feel again and heal.
author: Tara Walsh-Arpaia

comment:
She's high.
The scratching the shoulder, and arm is a tell tale sign.
Which is also the shaking of the head but responding the opposite.
The lack of emotion in her face and swaying of her head, also a sign.
The looking around and "subtle eye roll" is because she's not in control, she's an alpha control freaks being cornered.
The head on the hand is not boredom, it's nodding and sleepiness.
Like "you guys are killing my buzz"
The eating is her way of being in control, she will be rude and talk to you with her mouth full, or make you wait for an answer.
Her lawyers know she's high and rambling, that's why they kept objecting, they didn't want her to say a yes or no answer, they wanted her to explain that yes she did hit him and that it was self defense for her sister.
Which was a lie, and her "awareness" and angry defensiveness kicked in high gear trying to build up a hugely fabricated story.
Her lawyers have certainly coached her.
As for him.
His half smile and light laughter is something he has always done when telling personal information that he's uncomfortable with.
He was an enabler to her abuse.
And he knows it.
 And he's embarrassed about it, and you can see it in his responses.
Trying to make light of it instead of looking like a "battered husband" which I'm sure is embarrassing for any man.
But moreso to a man who is in the public eye, and who has worked so hard and built this sexy steamy persona with the ladies 
(although he is very shy and modest in reality and was never his intent).
But it sells, it pays the bills.
She is an alpha, a huge, huge, aggressive alpha.
And he is very timid, almost shy.
It's like she told him what to say as when he talks at the end, he is looking in her direction but at the ground out of the corner of his eye to see her body language.
He even says that they were discussing a trip, and at the very end, he even has his head down and asks her "right?"
And she responds, then he just separates away from her.
Like his job was done and the boss agreed to the job he just did.

comment:
I've been conflicted on this since allegations first came out. I'm not particularly attached to either of these celebrities. I try to just look at it like two random people.
The awkward nod/saying "no" at the beginning didn't seem suspect to me, because she was answered two questions at once "Do you understand?" (yes) and "Did you abuse Depp?" (no). I think she nodded to indicate she understood, then said "no" outloud. Awkward, but not suspicious. I also believe if Heard had been cool and collected, people would have still make the same accusations against her. I don't think it's outside the spectrum of possibility that she's tired and fatigued and nervous all at once, and that translates in her deposition. 

I watched this video because I'm open to all possibilities here. I found your channel from the Demi "sorry not sorry" apology video, and was impressed by your objective approach. I didn't find that same approach from you this time. For example, you ask why isn't she more interested in the beginning on the video. Later, when she IS emotional, you say "interesting" but still no.
Also, her lawyer was definitely edgy. That raised more flags for me than Heard's actual behavior. I know that being under the influence can make someone a different person, which could have happened with Depp. Unfortunately, I'm still undecided on this one. I think probably both people acted deplorably, but I'll never be sure.
Try not to flame me, I'm just being honest.

comment:
I don't know that quick answers with food in someone's mouth is a good indicator, a short answer yes, no, three or four words, I think it is somewhat common to clear your mouth for longer more complex answers. That complexity may indicate avoidance. When she says she was trying to escape she uses very laboredly dispassionate language and shakes her head, which seems more consistent with not believing what she is saying.. So the problem you have is in martial arts, they teach you to engage long enough for your escape, the state of Minnesota has a duty to withdraw, and military training teaches rules of engagement. Meaning if she has had martial arts training, was in the military, or knows the law, that story would become far more believable. I was in a physical altercation, where the exit was locked in a subway, I was forced to engage, I warned the other party, three times, then proceeded to defend my self with force after being struck by a mop, I engaged long enough to subdue the threats, and then stopped, when the police came the witnesses behind the counter relayed the story and it matched mine, the other party was arrested. If she had training like this several times in her life, it would seem like a dumb question. Especially, if you knew the law, had martial arts training and were in the military, you would think that is common knowledge. Someone's disinterest in a situation may come from assholes asking over and over again, you do get tired of it, the defensive gestures might be from trying to ward of a lawyer that just became a threat, the smile might indicate she knew what the lawyer was doing, thus showing she was a threat.

You mock her, it seems you have a bias against her here, the not answering the question after being asked three times, you here all the lawyers start to pipe up, she appears to be waiting for her lawyer to tell her to speak. So the answer was yes, she seems passionate, I think she might be telling the truth here. Johnny smirks, during his pause, that is pretty clear. 

Your statement is absolutely incorrect you couldn't be further from the truth, you should study people with very good memories, I can tell you the event in the subway, I can tell you where each person was standing, I can tell you where the mop bucket was, where my friend was standing. I can tell you the time, where the person behind the counter was, where the squad cars parked.. 
When I was arrested I can tell you where in the house I walked tell you I went to the gas station, so many details, I can tell you the color of the carpet, where the couches were, I can tell you if the curtains were closed in which rooms, what color the paint was on the walls, where each person was standing, I can tell you that the coffee table had a maroon stain top and black legs, the lamp on the table was black and gold base. There was a tower lamp by the switches by the door, the dimmer had lost its nob, and one of the switches was removed, There were scone lights on the way to the basement, there was a lion photo on the wall going down to the basement. in the living room, there was a Thomas Kincade tapestry, with my ex's degrees in frames on the wall, there were long mirrors on the dining room wall. I remember all of this, in vivid detail because my ex and I picked out all those colors, painted those walls, and I resurfaced the coffee table, hung the tapestry, laid the carpet, with some help on the carpet stretching, but I did a majority of the work and carried in those hundred lb rolls of carpet. I remember what was said, where people were,...  It made me a little angry to hear that. So when people question your ability to remember I would say some people prove it be describing details all parties know existed and can be proven with purchase records, IE there are purchases on my credit cards and my ex credit cards proving she bought the paint at home depot, conclusive, rock-solid evidence. Also, they might add details because they know the tactics the other side might use, like saying they did all the work when the reality is, they both did some, though the one that was home more likely did more to maintain it. I remodeled the basement mostly by myself with exception of the cleanup and hanging drywall where I need help with the ceiling. This is an important detail because it would directly refute claims that I was parasitic as I was maintaining the home WHILE working, and doing the cooking on the weekends by making salads, soups, and sandwiches, though we implemented a rule after I got tired of doing it alone where the family had to help prepare the weeks meals with me. That is important in case someone says I took all the credit, I vacuumed the entire basement by hand with a shop vac that is important in case someone says I didn't do housekeeping, I did all the carpet cleaning.  Just because you don't understand the relevance of certain pieces of information does not mean it isn't important to the overall picture. What it demonstrates is your lack of understanding of the law and how people discredit one another in relationship battles.  Statements like he was never around refuted by the fact that I could work remotely and was available, Statements that I never wanted to do anything fun, refuted by the camping and boating trips that SHE enjoyed. what utter garbage.

comment:
I enjoy watching these videos very much, but at the same time, looking at the comments (and real life), I find it very disconcerting how much trust people put in body language analysis. People mistake it for evidence, when it's nothing more than an unreliable indication that requires actual investigation to unearth actual evidence.



Body language analysis is the posterchild of the soft sciences. It's based on an individual's interpretation of deeply personal behaviors that, more often than not, have completely contradictory definitions. A smile can indicate actual happiness, or it can be a manifestation of extreme discomfort. 



Body language defies standardized application because a person's behavior, due to circumstances/upbringing, can be completely unique to them. In which case it's like trying to understand Chinese by using a Spanish dictionary: there might be a word in Chinese that's also a word in Spanish, but obviously they won't have the same meaning. Establishing a "base line" by watching a couple of videos for reference, is the equivalent of trying to learn Chinese in a couple of minutes. You'll learn a couple of words, sure, but you will not be sufficiently fluent to justify you functioning as translator for this uniqe human being.

comment: My trick for remembering vs faking is to look at the hands while the narration happens. For an invented story, the sense I get is distinctly one like a director setting up a shot. It is hard to describe, but instant recognition when you see it. There are more "revised" hand movements like you place something here, then another thing there, then you move them a bit so they fit better.... not exact description. When remembering, gestures are often less and rarely revised/moved when setting up the scene, because all the pointing happens to the remembered location of things. Maybe it could be "tricked" with a physical rehearsal of the claimed event before having to describe to have remembered locations for the hands to gesture at in the scene, but I don't think very many do that. Most times, you look at the hands, and you see a director telling the crew how the shot is set up and go "not what happened, is it?" Also the body movements are more "real" - for lack of a better descriptor. Like most people remembering going through a door placed behind them will turn around as though reaching for a handle rather than over their shoulder - which would not be how they actually approached the door.

comment:
Several decades of empirical research have shown that none of the non-verbal signs assumed by psychological folklore to be diagnostic of lying vs. truthfulness is in fact a reliable indicator of lying vs. truthfulness (Vrij, 2000, 2008; Vrij et al., 2019). It is a substantial literature. Vrij's (2008) seminal book included more than 1,000 references to the research literature and the recent review by Vrij et al. (2019) identified 206 scientific papers published in 2016 alone. Thus, any reliable non-verbal cues to lies and deceit ought to have been identified by now, anno 2020. However, the conclusions drawn by DePaulo et al. (2003), who analyzed 116 studies more than 15 years ago, still appear to be valid. They concluded that ‚Äúthe looks and sounds of deceit are faint,‚Äù and the recent review by Vrij et al. (2019) seconded this: ‚Äú‚Ä¶the non-verbal cues to deceit discovered to date are faint and unreliable and ‚Ä¶ people are mediocre lie catchers when they pay attention to behavior.‚Äù In other words, no reliable non-verbal cues to deception have to-date been identified. 

https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2020.613410/full

comment: I think it‚Äôs normal that she stumbled on the questioning about her committing domestic abuse. If she was defending herself she likely would have committed domestic abuse but admitting that only serves to minimise the abuse she suffered (which is why his lawyer asked this line of questioning to begin with). Also her not pausing when she had her mouth full and then pausing later when she had her mouth full is completely immaterial. In the latter, she had a noticeably larger quantity of food in her mouth. Not one piece of body language identified in this video constitutes grounds for establishing her guilt/innocence. Johnny Depp lost a defamation (libel) case. The only defence to defamation is truth. The fact that he lost, I‚Äôll be it on the balance of probabilities, is actually telling that Amber is being truthful. It‚Äôs certainly more telling than a body language reading. This feels like a biased (potentially misogynistic) character assassination based on pseudoscience which is why this type of evidence isn‚Äôt weighted heavily in court, if it‚Äôs even deemed admissible at all.

author: Stacy Alpine

comment:
I can't watch this, I know it will trigger my ptsd and I am not even going to try. I just want to say for the people in the comments section that part of the struggle domestic violence victims face is the expectation that if you aren't an absolute angel then you aren't a victim. The truth is, domestic violence is messy. The truth is, you don't know how you are going to react until you feel trapped and your adrenaline in making you sick to your stomach. I tried so hard to do the right thing, to do the least harm, to walk away, and sometimes run away. But I couldn't, always. And despite how often I tried to do the right thing, the least harmful thing, despite how much I tried to get him on the same page and recognize that this was not safe or healthy and needed to change, in the end he didn't care about me enough to stop. In the end, I lost almost everything. It has taken years to rebuild. 

Men can absolutely be victims of domestic violence, and they deserve support and help when they are. However, it doesn't look the same as when women are victims of domestic violence, it plays out differently because of the role society plays, so we can't expect them to look the same. Also, male perpetrators of domestic violence ALWAYS say, "she was abusive too." They believe it; the problem is they equate you drawing boundaries and expressing your negative emotions in a direct way to them hitting you, destroying your things, hurting your pets and loved ones, etc... Idk what is going on with these two people. I know that people who experience trauma can't always walk you through what happened with perfect clarity, because your brain wants to protect you from that. 

I am not really commenting on the video, but about domestic violence in general, because knowledge is power. Sorry for the essay. One last thing, maybe we could all just put in the work to prevent domestic violence from happening, make the world a better place for the next generation.
author: Rachel K

comment: I respect your knowledge but have you researched how victims of abuse sometimes present? Confusion, disdain, are things I can relate to. If she is lying, then surely she would have tried to act the victim more. She's not trying to come across as a victim, which is not necessarily a bad thing. I'm not passing judgement on whether Amber is innocent,  but I'm just worried that your analysis isn't taking into account the protective tics victims sometimes (have) to use. If she is actually a victim, this questioning would be immensely distressing for her and no wonder she seems odd? Again - I don't actually think she is the victim here, but do think your analysis should have mentioned that more clearly, or given expert opinion from an abuse expert on how victims can react.
