comment:
I‚Äôm disappointed. I was really looking forward to an analysis on their body language while in court, but there are too many misunderstandings and points not being noticed. 

For example:

She nodded her head that she understood the question and responded ‚Äúno‚Äù to the question.. I feel like this isn‚Äôt taking into the account that this has been a very long, very public case in which Amber has been attacked on many platforms by many of Depp‚Äôs fans. Yes, her body clearly states that she‚Äôs contradicting herself, but it is understandable that she doesn‚Äôt want to be there. Not necessarily because she‚Äôs guilty, but more likely because she‚Äôs tired of the abuse she‚Äôs receiving from the public throughout the trial.

The licking on the side of the mouth could be an indication of nerves, resulting in a dry mouth. As someone who struggles with anxiety, I recognize this symptom. The corners of your mouth get dry and cracked and it becomes difficult to talk, so you subconsciously lick the area to lubricate so you can speak without trouble. However, it could also be caused by salty food.

At 14:43 there is an eye flutter. She did indeed hear that question, and her eyes indicate that the statement is untrue.


No, I am not a fan of hers. Before this case I didn‚Äôt even know her name. However, I can clearly see that she is purposefully acting bored. She is clearly nervous and there are signs of depression, but she‚Äôs acting blas√© to try and show her innocence. 
Please remember that should she be innocent, her discomfort is understandable. She‚Äôs being publicly accused of lying and being an abuser herself, and she is clearly losing this case. Abusive victims hardly ever come forward as it is humiliating to have their trauma replayed for strangers to judge. At this point she probably feels as if she‚Äôs already lost the battle, although she is sticking to her guns and seeing the trial through to the end instead of appealing for a lighter sentence or settlement of some kind, which means she has something to fight for.

 I fully support Johnny, however I feel that this video isn‚Äôt being entirely fair, taking into consideration how both parties may feel at this point, and it is certainly not unbiased. Seeing as this is a legal case, it‚Äôs not right to cast judgement from the get-go. I would‚Äôve preferred a more detailed analysis based purely on her actions, without pre-studying the video so that their are no pre-formed opinions.

I like the idea behind this video, but hope future ones might take my words into account.
author: Kai Ives

comment: I'm not a body language expert or anything but I do watch a lot of ID channel & body language/non-verbal ques are fascinating to me. You pointed out a few things I noticed in Amber's non-verbal ques that I agree with and also pointed out and explained a lot for Johnny & Amber separately and together that I didn't notice. Very insightful. When I first heard they were dating I thought they were cute but I also wondering if she was just using Johnny. Then I heard about their marriage and thought it was quick based on Johnny's past relationships - shocked and kinda thought it was a red flag. If the genders were reversed serious alarms would have been going off because a rush to the altar seems possibly controlling. When the accusations flew I stayed neutral until both parties revealed their perspective of the truth. I'm a feminist on Johnny's side. Need to say that because it seems feminists are taking Amber's side without questions just because she's a woman. I hate how Amber is potentially damaging the efforts to stop domestic violence against women and may as well be openly mocking the survivors of abuse. On the other hand she's showing everyone something equally important I became aware of years ago: that women can be the abusers, that men can be abused by women regardless of their age or size in comparison. While many women don't come forward with abuse, even less men come forward if they're abused. Especially if the abuser is a woman. Women AND men should be able to tell their side without judgement or ridicule from anyone and assumed innocent until PROVEN guilty with solid evidence.

comment:
I'm at 5:05 to 5:20 , 5:50 at the moment and would to add something.
As someone with ADHD, the looking around while talking is normal for us. 
I'm not saying she has it but please remember those of us with ADHD.

Example: I was with three other people at subways, we all have ADHD, out faces and eyes were wondering around the entire time. Our phones were out and we were messing with them. But our bodies were all pointed towards each other. Me were moving alot paying attention to out side and inside while have a conversation with each other. I was taking to my friend Sky and a girl as well as the other guy there. While Sky, he was talking to me and the other guy. The other guy and the girl were having a conversation while he talked to Sky. 


For me:
People say when they speak to me I'm not really listening but I am. And if I was to focus on you in full, body and eyes, they tend to get uncomfortable and lose their train of thoughts. 
Which is why I don't look people in the eyes when I talk. Only when it is needed. Even though I'm soft spoken, I do have a tendency when you have my full attention.  My friends can contest to that.

comment: Why do you think victims should have a desire to be in a courtroom? The situation is frustrating, boring, and tedious no matter what type of courtroom or the potential outcome for every person involved expect perhaps those actually being paid to be there.  It‚Äôs not any more enjoyable just because you might get to claim some scrap of justice has been served.  Her entire life is being disrupted as a result of her husband beating her and as if that wasn‚Äôt enough, she has to spend hours with lawyers & judges and deposition takers so of course she doesn‚Äôt want to be there. I‚Äôve been through that experience on a much smaller scale bc of the lack of public scrutiny & I‚Äôm sure I seemed just as disinterested.  She was in her mid 20s & her biggest mistake was marrying an asshole who conned her and MILLIONS of others into thinking he was a decent guy. Who wouldn‚Äôt be frustrated? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I really think you‚Äôre missing the mark on this analysis. I subscribed to your channel after watching your Olivia Jade Red Table analysis but you might have lost me as a subscriber after this one. Did you consider that she was just hungry and chose a snack food bc it wouldn‚Äôt be messy or stink up the room? Women‚Äôs lives are extremely hectic and a lot of us are juggling so much we‚Äôre stuck eating on the go. At this point I think you‚Äôre being a bit judgmental.  You‚Äôve attacked her manners, her diet & eating habits and I‚Äôm not even halfway through the video.

comment:
I‚Äôm an attorney and although I am not a litigator, I have sat in depositions and even been deposed myself.
In 25 years, I have NEVER, ever seen someone eat and loudly chew through a deposition such as this.
I do not know why Depp‚Äôs lawyers allowed this to continue.
Not only is it straight up rude, it makes it incredibly difficult for a court reporter to hear what someone is saying while they speak while eating.
I‚Äôve seen judges demand deponents remove gum from their mouths when I didn‚Äôt think the chewing was especially loud. 
Judges normally don‚Äôt sit in during depositions, but will if there are problems and IIRC, AH was refusing to even appear for a deposition.
Much like how she is now ignoring a court‚Äôs order to provide proof she donated all $7MM of her settlement as she agreed to do
author: Chee Chalker

comment:
After watching there is clear indication that Amber Heard is a liar and abuser, but I can also see why people haven't been believing Johnny Deep with that unsettling half-smile tick. Ashame if they took that into account, but NOT all of Amber Heard's oddities.

ALSO- as a mental health counselor in training, I can tell you his half smile is _likely_ a defense mechanism we call sublimation: expressing the opposite emotion in the face of feeling a very uncomfortable emotion. This type of defense mechanism in particular manifests almost unwillingly/subconsiously. (In his case, automatically smiling when being forced to recall a really bad memory and quietly laughing while describing bodily harm).

comment:
I've been in a relationship with someone this toxic..

I will never forget when my ex (year long relationship) accused me of cheating when I'd didn't. At 24 years old I was working every day and night to pay the bills and was getting 3 hours of sleep every night from working 3 jobs. She was going to school and living off of my income. I got tired of it and I said "if you're going to falsely accuse me of always cheating than I might as well do it anyways".

She pulled a knife on me in my own kitchen and told me I wouldn't live to tell the story. She even asked me "even if I was to stab you in 'self defense' who do you think the cops would believe you as a man or me?". She even started fake crying with a knife pointed at my stomach while I was doing dishes and started talking to me as if she was speaking to cops afterwards.. saying things  in a sobbing voice like "he was coming at me and I didn't know what to do".

I then planned my escape that weekend afterwards, and moved out.. bought a gun (carry it on me 24/7) and have never looked back. But all I remember thinking all the time is there's women out there who are this crazy, abusive and hide that they think this way. They will hurt or threaten anyone to get what they want.

Still to this day my current wife tells me I have issues trusting people (like friends and family). We even reflected and it took me about a year or two to properly fall asleep overnight in the same bed together since we've started. I always tell her you would too after what I've dealt with.
author: Specter Green

She was known for her aggressive and angry demeanor and never seemed genuinely sweet or kind. Her posturing and attitude were always narcissistic and egotistical. 

Depp is far from a perfect human being, but his exes spoke up for him. What baffles me is it‚Äôs almost hypocritical Heard is to be believed yet his exes weren‚Äôt. I‚Äôll stand by Depp and believe him. Men can be victims of abuse just as much as women.

comment:
I agree with your points. What i pick up from this is:
She's uncomfortable, bites her lower lip whenever asked if she was violent towards Depp (an act that usually indicates guilt or feeling uncomfortable with what you're about to say), she stumbles in her wording and she is defensive, keeping her arms tight to her body, tense posture. Generally speaking, someone that is accused wrongly of something they didn't do would get angry and offensive. Not leaning back or away from the interviewer but towards them to establish dominance and keep make a stance. This is done to indicate clearly and strongly that the accusation is false. Whenever asked a yes or no she occasionally gives a wordy answer that deviates from the question. She's not involved into the discussion at all either.. She doesn't care at all... She's angry but PAUSES and dodges the question when their questions are tougher or that position her in a negative light, therefore it means she doesn't have an answer ready.. you would know what to answer when it already happened because is the truth and it is an easy answer BUT if the truth condemns you... then... you wouldn't rush it: example 17:35 there is no passion involved.. *time to think* 19:35 Confident answer + passion in her words. To me this is clear indicator of a lie.. all of it is.

I appreciate your video ad analysis of this.

comment:
As an actual victim of domestic violence I find what she‚Äôs doing appalling. I suffered extreme physical mental emotional and psychological abuse at the hands of my ex-husband for six years.  I have had countless broken bones which included A broken arm, a cracked skull , several broken ribs and he hit me so hard and dry broke my do out. He beat me so bad during my pregnancy that I almost lost my child and was put in the hospital for months. Psychological psychological abuse was just as bad as his fists. He belittled me, criticize me for every little thing, blamed me for his shortcomings, and broke me down made me feel like I was nothing and completely broke my spirit. It took years to be able to aging the courage to leave him. I left him with our two children $200 to my name. 
She is not only making a mockery of every woman who has suffered but the hands of an abuser she is a classic abuser her self who is trying to justify her actions because she has a self-righteous attitude and believes she can play victim and get away with it. She‚Äôs disgusting. She is using the movement that is meant for true victims to try to ruin a man‚Äôs life for financial gain and sympathy in hopes to boost her career. I honestly think she never loved him , she‚Äôs been a Golddigger from day one. 
Oh and as a sidenote Johnny Depp‚Äòs reactions are those of a man that suffers from abuse, it comes from the embarrassment from the stigma it brings. There are so many men that suffer domestic abuse that don‚Äôt report it because of the out right embarrassment of admitting that a woman is abusing them. Other men can be extremely harsh and even the law can as they find it hard for a ‚Äútiny little woman‚Äù to be the aggressor. Men don‚Äôt report it for the sympathy because it brings backlash of criticism and disbelief. You can see his embarrassment and shame. I have been in several support groups that included men and I see in the very same luxe and I‚Äôve seen them speak of their trauma in the exact same way. His pain is genuine, her story is rehearsed and poorly acted. You would think for an actress she could make a better performance to sound convincing but nope because she‚Äôs so arrogant she just believes that we will believe whatever she says. She‚Äôs a lier and a horrible person. I absolutely will not be watching any movie she‚Äôs in nor will I purchase any product that she‚Äôs a representative of. 
Sorry for the long rant but True victim need a voice and liars should be called out.

comment: In Johnny's pauses, I heard a lot of this in the recordings of them in private and I noticed it started in all of his interviews from about a year or so into their relationship thru recently and its very familiar to me... then I heard in 2 of the recordings where he started to become lucid and questioning her, making good points but was not agitated at all and she pulled out a pill bottle and made him take tranquilizers.  I recognized it when I first started seeing it in interviews,  it was even more obvious in the recordings between them and then I heard her actually tell him to take them as soon as he started getting a handle on what she was really doing to him. He was tranqed big time. Ive heard it when I was on them after my trauma, I've heard it in patients, it even reminds me of Stevie Nicks interviews during her klonopin years. Its a very obvious disconnect and slow draw. Plus hes definitely using dark humor to cope and try to make less of things. Its obvious how old habit it is for him to minimize, downplay and try to joke off to make himself and others comfortable with her toxic behavior that he's even doing it here. If u learn about his mother, its obvious he had experience with this throughout his formative years as well.

comment: I'm so glad u saw everything in this that I saw when I first watched it... how bored, dismissive, sparky, cavalier,  disinterested... just not how u act when ur traumatized, not only that, but SHE'S AN ACTRESS, I mean on that alone she should have been able to do better than this but I think that just further shows how narcissistic she is that she just believes (and mind bogglingly, rightfully so) that everyone's going to buy her line no matter what, so this is just a waste of her time and not worth even bothering to try. Its all so wrong. And now the press is saying Johnny blew up his life by trying to set the record straight.  SHE SINGLE-HANDEDLY UNDID METOO. She brought back the fable of the life ruining, lying victim AND got everyone, whether they believe her or not, to victim blame him. AND SHE'S GETTING PAID TO DO IT AS AN ADVOCATE. As someone who has suffered domestic violence and spends my life counseling other victims, this absolutely sickens me.
author: potato pirate

comment: I have never, in all of the dom abuse victims i have counseled, and especially not in myself, I have NEVER seen a person who has been traumatized, be able to eat like that and behave so cavalier while discussing it. She's not comfort seeking eating, she's bored eating and time buying. Even with victims who play the tough guys as a coping mechanism,  there is a notable somber tone change when addressing actual moments of abuse. Nevermind that after I saw this I heard the audio of her discussing this same event with him in private and she clearly admitted details which meant he was the one locked in, she was trying to get in and angry at him for leaving and that she hit him with her hand in the face after the door opened, of course she made sure to keep the whole convo focused on the fact that the door scratched her toe when it swung open.... still boggles my mind that that didn't prove anything in court. Victims come in all shades and presentations but I've never seen such a blatant example of an abuser posing as a victim before. As a survivor, i can't bare this.

comment:
Opinion of some random guy on the internet who has no knowledge on the topic. Listen to the professionals, not me. Just sharing my opinion because it's the first thought that came to my untrained mind. Eating can also be a way of reducing stress, not necessarily a lack of regard for the process. Obviously she doesn't want to be there, but here behaviors seem more to reflect discomfort, distress, and being emotionally drained. I know we are looking at her as a perpetrator, not a victim, in this scenario. But, even if that's true, it gives us a bias in interpreting her behavior. I don't know anything about this situation and this video is the first time I'm hearing about this, I don't even know who this woman is. But maybe an outside perspective that does not carry preconceptions is a good thing? Like maybe she did hit him, but I see her as very emotionally affected by the process, and she is suppressing loads of distress, and is emotionally drained. But I wouldn't conclude that she is apathetic to the situation. Just my opinion, that's all. Not intending to fight, you can disagree if you want. I also think she's super frustrated with the redundancy of the process.
Maybe analyze videos of her response when she first answered these questions? Like the redundancy of the process can explain her attitude, not necessarily the fact she guilty.

comment: OR...... the nod of the head is an affirmative that she understood the question whereas "no" is her answer to the question of whether she committed domestic violence against Depp. Also, is it so hard to believe that a possible victim of domestic violence may feel uncomfortable in a deposition that touches on such a sensitive and personal subject that they may very well not want to be there, feel the need to self sooth etc. You are reading her body language but perhaps her body language is not all directed towards the questions posed to her. I'm sure the circumstances she finds herself in, the setting in which the depo is held in, revisiting trauma by being asked these questions are all part of the body language you're reading. Think about it - this depo and other hearings she may have had to attend are all  prelude to a nasty trial where her opponent outranks her in wealth and thus his legal fire power would be quite intimidating I imagine. I wouldn't want to be there either if I was her and I'd be self soothing, shaking my head and everything else, gulping water, sweating bullets and shitting bricks etc., but it wouldn't mean I'm untruthful - just NERVOUS!

comment:
For Johnny Depp, I kind of relate to his sudden smirks that don't really reach his eyes. I have a very unfriendly face, it's been told to me multiple times throughout my life and I daydream a lot, which means my face looks angry but I'm actually playing elevator music in my head. I've been told, constantly, drilled into me even, to always smile. This makes other people more at ease with my unfriendly face, apparently.

I always do these smirks, or corner of lip lifts, because of my naturally downturned mouth conveying frowning. It's like an appeasement to the person talking to me, like a "no, I'm not upset by you" situation. His mouth, at rest, also looks downturned, and his brow looks furrowed most of the time. He could be smirking unconsciously to appease the people he's speaking to, because he does the same in the Japanese video.

It could be. I'm just theorising.

comment:
I have to admit I only skimmed the first ~20 comments or so, alas if someone else has mentioned this before: SORRY. BUT: 

Is NO ONE pointing out 15:30  "..and Johnny, whenever he was injured or touched at all, he would always refer to it in these ways: punching, or clocked, or whatever....and whether you discussed it with him or not." 

This statement literally admits she knows in detail how Johnny describes being the victim and how he reacts to the ensuing discussion after the fact. She then tries to play it down by insinuating he would categorize a gentle push as "cold clocking". This seems extremely far fetched and a way of wiggling out of her previous statement. 

Occam's Razor principle: usually the explanation with the least amount of assumptions is the right one. Here this leads to only one solution: her knowing his reaction is that she regularly hit him. 


Res ipsa loquitur = the matter (evidence) speaks for itself.  Case Closed.

comment: This analysis is totally ridiculous. He says she is not emotional or passionate therefore "fishy", now when he is not emotional or passionate then he is soft spoken and genuine....you already made up you mind about who is lying and it doesn't matter who says what. To you she is guilty and him innocent. If she is playing the victim, you said she isn't acting like the victim. By that logic it mean he is the actual victim, however he isn't acting like a victim either. You analysis is total bullshit. I dont like her. But judging someone by body language is not a valid method of finding out who is telling the truth. Also different people deal with the same situation differently. Also I have done depositions and all my lawyer keep repeating to me is to not get emotional. To tone it down the passion bc if I get excited it sound like a lie to them. Its difficult. Its aggrevating, its uncomfortable and lawyer ask questions specifically knowing what the answer will be without allowing you to explain Which then makes you look like a liar. They twist every word you say to suit their client. Its infuriating, bc you realize they dont want the truth. They want to win.

comment:
These videos make me realize how often I "mouth shrug" when I'm just thinking of an answer. Truthful answers. Or even not an answer, just a response in a conversation. I guess that would just be part of my baseline though?
On the subject of putting her chin in her hands saying she's "Bored". Which I do not disagree with.  But if your significant other does this...it could mean their next hurts, they're tired, etc. I have chronic health and fatigue issues that cause just the meager strain of holding my head up to hurt my neck and I get tired as a result of trying to deal with literally constant pain. So I tend to put my head in my hands a lot in an attempt to relieve some of the pain I'm in.
You really should try not to speak in absolutes so often.

comment: Amber seems all over the place, she seems to be a high energy person. For TV interviews, I think they prescreen the questions so they know what they have to say ahead of time. Worst case scenario, drugs could be having an impact on her behaviour. Wouldn't be the first time a celebrity has had drug problems. The important thing to remember is that we can never know the whole story, and people are rarely completely innocent of any wrongdoings, even when suffering most of the abuse.

comment:
"Little Richard" üòÜ
Basically it means little dick. As he recalled the injury he was recalling the joke he'd been using about the finger that got hurt, the birdie. Mine got injured once, I accidently gave a dr the bird when asked which finger got hurt, but I was 8 or so at the time. Was probably some forced positivity, it's a bittersweet joke instead of thinking only about pain.
I have chronic pain. Humour is sometimes necessary for it.
While I don't like what Amber has done I get a sense she was oversimplistically misunderstood in these videos, and perhaps things you said were present in various footage you saw but in these tidbits it comes across a lot less concrete. So while I've seen other footage of her and can understand many concerns of her behaviour, if relying on this video alone I would have more doubts.
I could easily think she was exhausted, and she may have missed a meal and missed sleep. I wouldn't doubt it much given the hot mess she's in, but it doesn't seem overall relevant to the topic. I do believe she mentally struggles to communicate and has mental health issues, which need to be appropriately addressed, which I don't think are.
The first problem you pointed out was weird to point out in the instance, even if normally considered a thing. In this instance though she takes time to process what is said and what to say; you already established that was normal for her. Right during processing she was asked a second question. She had two different answers and so then had to process how to answer, again. She made it clear where the problem was when she clarified "yes I understand the question." while trying to say no to the first question. She didn't have to doubt her answers to doubt how to communicate them.
When asked if she ever punched Depp with a closed fist, she answered yes. Multiple times, but no doubt with strong feelings preventing her being utterly clear she was actually answering. I believe she feels a regret of sorts, not that it really changes her guilt.
It would be more unusual for her not to have strong feelings to a question about her doing something wrong, whether having done it or not. I believe her, she said she hit him. She then got defensive saying what lead up to it. Whether that part is true or not... I think she really wants to believe it is. She rose with conviction and literally went red in the face and neck regarding her sister. She slipped her temper. In the heat of the moment she may really have believed there was a danger even if there wasn't one because she was seeing red at the time. She needs a good therapist to help her manage her emotions and help her with her processing ability.
However regarding Depp she needs to apologize publicly, and leave him be. She's ruined his life and she had no right or excuse to be so vindictive. The most frightening for her thing she could do is understand and accept what she's done. She doesn't want to be seen as the bad guy.
For her sake and everyone else's, I really hope she gets the right mental health care.

comment: So i find it actually fairly common for the smirk to be in place in an abusive relationships. I personally remember doing this after telling people of my abuse story. Her "individual characteristics" of keeping her eyelids looking the same size; the eye shifting, unconcerned or distractedness; those things are affected and practiced.  
This young woman has spent hours upon hours in front of a mirror training herself to always smile in an attractive way, hold her eyes in an attractive way, discourage wrinkles, etc.  The slightly narrowed eyes and looking out the corners of her eyes everywhere, as though distracted, reminds me of Greta Garbo -in character in a few famous roles.

Johnny wasn't going to put up with that forever and she had to figure out a way to come out looking like a rose and the victim. Johnny has always been a humble gentle and kind soul. Yes, can he get angry or have a temper? OFCOURSE we ALL do! But I would bet my life that this insane abuse she tries to blame on him, was the other way around. With the past few years and all the women comming forward and being brave about their sexual assault in the media and how large the women's rights movement has become in Hollywood etc she used that to her advantage to gain sympathy. She jumped right on that train! I am in no way bashing abuse or women for speaking up about assaults, or the women who spoke out against Harvey Weinstein and bill Cosby etc... I empathise as a woman myself who has been raped at 15 by a 25 year old man. I have nothing but respect for those who speak out. My point is, I think she used the anger and frustration towards that whole situation to her advantage knowing so many would sympathize and lump her with another victim of abuse and run with it. And a chance to tear a HUGE a list star down. What a way to sell magazine's! Everyone jumped on board. Her "good looks" didn't hurt either. Although, her personality makes her very ugly imo. 
Anyway sorry for rambling. I'm just furious at what her lies have done to him. He didn't deserve what she has done. Thank God there are many who also aren't falling for her bullshit.

comment: As someone who has been abused throughout their childhood and witnessed their parents‚Äô extremely unhealthy relationship, I‚Äôve learned to trust my gut regarding these matters. I don‚Äôt like Amber Heard. She seems to show signs of frustration and anger throughout that first interrogation as if she is being treated unfairly and things aren‚Äôt going her way, which I find very peculiar. A victim of abuse does not act like that when they are asked about their trauma - her behaviour shows signs of a narcissistic personality. I‚Äôm not saying that Depp is innocent - it is impossible to know if you don‚Äôt know the people personally, and even then it may be difficult. I just really don‚Äôt like Amber Heard. I tend to smile and laugh about the trauma that I went trough, because I don't want people to feel bad about the shit I had to put up with. It's also partly dark humor that I develop to cope with the trauma.
So, I would guess he might have similar reasons. Plus, other people also mentioned possible reasons for him half smiling. 
The hesitation could very well be to gaslighting, and other types of emotional and psychological abuse. Which makes you doubt your own memory and emotions. And from the way A.H. acts and behaves it seems highly likely that she did stuff like this. 

I'm genuinely sad and angry Johnny had to go through something like this. I wish for him to recover from this abuse as much as possible and hope he will receive justice.

comment: I always thought this was an everybody-thing, apparently it isn't, but at least for myself I can confirm that I do this smile/laugh-thing all the time when I talk about uncomfortable, shameful or traumatic experiences. I don't know exactly why I do it, but I would assume it's somewhat of a desperate attempt at not looking weak and showcasing that I am "fine and¬†whatever happen doesn't concern me anymore". Either that or it's a coping mechanism to soothe myself by making the situation appear less severe than it actually was. No one wants to have bad things happen to them or to be a victim, so it's easier to just brush it off to keep your mind at ease.

comment:
I hate her with a burning passion! I've been saying for years (before the abuse claims) that she isn't healthy for him. He along with a lot of soft spoken men get taken advantage of and abused. I've seen it many times, male victims don't get the justice they deserve which is why most of them bear it in silence with a smile.

 I've seen it first hand with my male cousin who came to family events with deep cut wounds on his face and yet his girlfriend would tell his parents he was being 'mean' to her. He said nothing, he played with their toddler son and kept his head down. He smiled and laughed but never commented on his face. It took months for him to confide in anyone that she locked him on their apartment balcony and was throwing glass plates at his head in front of their toddler. 

Male victims need to be heard! They are suffering and no one is doing enough to help them. It's bullshit!

author: hahaha 00

comment:
Clearly another presentation by someone lacking knowledge of dynamics of abuse between more vulnerable narcissistic presenting abusers and those that have been subjected to and dealing with that type of abuser. You state multiple times victim blaming statements, as from the start you don‚Äôt consider her not wanting to be there from a victim stance. Your assumptions and bias clearly reflect throughout, and you even go on to predict it yourself, indeed based on your limited knowledge of such dynamics, you were beating a dead horse of not understanding domestic violence and the myriad of ways it presents, aside from the more socially projected images and narratives. and those in the comments supposedly victims of abuse themselves clearly did not experience the same levels or types of manipulation inherent in certain abusive situations.  If you were, then her statement and interviews would make more sense, and no, a victim of that type of abuse would actually be more likely to try to give more details, and an expert covert liar would want to keep his/her statements brief...much more could be said, and sadly much of the videos on this topic and commenters lack knowledge, and/or biased.  Also, no one should say how a victim should react, you have made multiple statements as have supposed victims in comments of ‚Äúshould‚Äù and how they reacted and ‚Äúwould never eat‚Äù etc. it‚Äôs mind boggling the lack of awareness and seething disdain for her based on her not following a socially dominant image of victim, thus why he comes off looking that way and why actual knowledge of abuse systems and victims experiences and dynamics and tactics used would dispel such horrid biased ‚Äúanalysis‚Äù.  As a side note, narcissists view people as objects, take a look at his words in that abhorrent text regarding her and how it isn‚Äôt just someone angry at her, but how he views women more generally, and while not relevant if you are going to just go off made up leaps and persona bias, may I remind ya‚Äôll he is/was friends with RomanPolanksky, the admitted predator of minors who escaped the country to avoid sentencing, but you know, let‚Äôs all just continue to talk out of our biased arse‚Äôs about things we only know from media and how we think things would look, rather than hearing the person and trying to understand what this would look like if she is telling the truth, how all your points would actually be able to be explained or hypothesized just as casually as you did in the reverse, but not once did you bother to try that, instead short cutting to victim blaming ‚Äúif you were a victim you would behave look like xyz‚Äù domestic violence 101, a victim does not have to act a certain way, doesn‚Äôt have to conform to a imaginary script, and indeed its that pressure to come off a certain way in order to be believed that is part of what makes responding stressful and difficult to pinpoint the direction it would look to someone unfamiliar with the dynamics, let alone when your being accused of being the primary aggressor, not just reporting to police.
Regardless on the actual situation between these two people, which we can‚Äôt actually speak on, my point is if you are going to demonize someone, or throw out comments and videos stereotyping reactions, you should be more informed of various abuse dynamics and the ways the genuine victims get falsely ‚Äúread‚Äù, s extremely harmful to our society to continue this narrative and informal interpretation, as it also shows a mind boggling blindness to inherit bias...
I short, this video, and these comments and other videos with similar comments sections are extremely problematic for those in domestic violence situations and it reinforces insecurity of the victim, speaking out, as such uneducated opinions formed on biased and socially informed expectations worsen the situation. It is dangerous to continue to practice this type of narrative of what victims should look like or sound like, particularly when their words and behaviors do align with many survivors in certain dynamics of abuse, yet much of society regurgitates the same shallow understanding, also some people just blatantly have a bias depending on other factors, which seems apparent in this case, btw it would be distracting  to be a victim of abuse and be accused and then people are whispering as you attempt to recall traumatic experiences, but of,course, you assumed she is lying, so...the insensitive reaction fits.  This whole video and others like it fits so well into angry assumptions, perhaps she is unlike able in her demeanor, like that first video, however, that doesn‚Äôt mean you can overlook the scenario she is explaining, because she makes actual sense, and you tried to pick times when she had her mouth full to answer a question that required much more detailed response question vs a simpler one, where she had less in her mouth to begin with, ( best example of grasping at straws I‚Äôve seen yet) also, just because she was chewing doesn‚Äôt mean she is doing it to bide time to lie (inane to think that‚Äôs the only explanation you put forth, an observation of  clear bias and limited interpretation options in ‚Äúobservation‚Äù in this video), it can be extremely nerve wracking and actual survivors need time in between questions, but aren‚Äôt usually given it, like serious there is so much blatant disturbing bias and lack of knowledge here that the community in the comments and elsewhere that clearly show showing empathy and being likable have nothing to do with being a victim. Not to mention, the most obvious marker of bias, literally trying to argue her confidence and his being charming, black and white ideas of what all abuse looks like....absurdity.

author: Visa

comment:
Subbed last night and this is the second of your videos that I've watched. One very strong thing I noticed in Amber was that its the lower half of her face which animates when she's talking naturally - the baseline showcased quite a range of mouth shapes, but her eyes and brow never moved! (With me, it's very much the other way around!). Yet in the deposition, her brow wrinkled quite a lot. And every time it did, she was saying something dodgy. I wonder if the brow-wrinkle is her particular 'tell' - when she's consciously working to convince someone of what she's saying, she engages more of her face in the performance; but when she's being herself, that part of her face is naturally inert.

And with that in mind, it was interesting to watch how much her mouth worked most of the time. It was as if she wanted to really give a massive monologue and was really having to work to keep from saying something she'd regret. I bet that's what the snacks were for - to keep that overactive mouth occupied. The moment when she leaned her chin on her hand was the point where it looked as if she was having to force her mouth to stay shut. Yes, she was signalling boredom and contempt, but she was doing that from the start. The chin on her hand was extra - forcibly keeping her mouth closed.

Overall, I didn't think this was the general behaviour of someone about to discuss the physical abuse they'd suffered from someone they'd previously loved and trusted. There was no grief, no fear and, most of all, no focus on the person questioning her and by doing so, casting doubt on her side of the story.  If she was a genuine victim, I would expect her to have her eyes fixed on the person questioning her. Maybe her mouth would work out of anxiety and the desire to talk about the crime committed against her - likewise self-soothing gestures. But she looked as if she was constantly looking for an escape route. Again, comparing with the baseline - she quite clearly didn't want to be there. But it wasn't fear - the overriding impression I got was of passionate anger barely suppressed of the 'how dare you question me, peasant!' variety.

Agree with everything you said about Depp. He didn't just stick to the point, he actually demonstrated what happened and then pointed to his scar caused by having the finger severed!

comment: Heard admits in the audio that she deliberately punched Johnny.  She then diverts to another incident rather that answering the question directly.  Johnny's lawyer isn't very good in questioning.  She could have specifically asked about what was said in the audio.  She also could have asked more information about where Amber was vis a vis Johnny in that incident.  Johnny was locked in a bathroom and she was trying to barrel into the bathroom.  The bathroom door opens into the bathroom which is why Amber hit him in the head with the door (which she admits to in the audio).  If she was trying to get away from him, did she start out in the bathroom?  What was she doing with him in the bathroom?  That would have exposed her lie about her getting away from him when it was him getting away from her.  The location of each person would also have exposed that she was pushing the door in to get access to Johnny rather than Johnny pulling on a door to get at her.
author: Been There

comment:
This is a complicated situation because personally, I understand where she's coming from. I know what its like to hit someone when they refuse to leave your space. They never actually hit you, but you hit them while trying to get away. Does that really make us an abuser? I also understand why she's coming off so defensive. I feel defensive when I tell people the things I've done to my ex partner while trying to get away from them. Ive scratched, punched, and pushed.  Ive threatened to stab him with scissors when he wouldn't let me close the door, similar to a situation amber was explaining. I'm always surpised when they tell me they would have done the same. I always expect a very different reaction. 

Also side note, I love Johnny Depp. However, he is a great actor and if he just so happens to be a narcissist as well, thats a very dangerous combo. I naturally believe him 100%. However I also know how charming and deceptive the real abusers can be. They always come off as the good person to others.

comment: I've seen some others analyze this deposition, and I think they all miss something. At the beginning, when she nods and then says "No," she might not be contradicting herself. Depp's lawyer asks if Heard has committed domestic violence, Heard pauses, Heard's lawyer objects, then Depp's lawyer asks whether Heard understood the question, then Heard nods and says, "No." So Heard might have nodded to affirm that she understood the question, then answered the question by saying "No."

comment: I am a survivor of DB. I had no idea who Heard even was, or even that Depp had left his last chick. I don‚Äôt pay attention to celebrities if I can help it. Yet, I found out about Heard when her allegations became public. As a survivor, my first instinct was to believe her, my heart went out to her! Then I saw this video, and every alarm bell went off in my head. I knew instantly this was a grift! Then I heard the entirety of those taped conversations, and I can tell you that it was Heard who reminded me of my abuser, and not the other way around. (BTW, that room Heard is claiming she was trying to escape to, was the bathroom in which Depp had locked himself into, in order to get away from her. That protection of the baby sister is laughable as well, considering her history of abusing her ‚Äúbaby‚Äù sister, and kicking her out of the Penthouse)  It was the Text between Depp, and Heards mother that closed the case to me. This person is a sociopath, a jackal. She is single handedly destroying ‚Äúme too‚Äù. I never been invested in any celebrity drama, but after what I experienced in my own life, I feel strongly about Depps vindication. This store is truly evil.

comment: Seeing Johnny and Amber together towards the end of the video was actually a little shocking when you look at it a bit more closely. I almost wonder if Amber is a bit jealous and insecure with all of the attention Johnny is getting. I mean, the interviewer is asking him questions and not her. It sort of feels like she's trying to make it clear to everyone that she's his focus and therefore more important between the two of them. Johnny looked terrified when Amber initially looked down on him almost with an aggressive, sly smirk. "You better acknowledge we're together and that you're here with me because I'm the love of your life and I deserve some attention if you're getting some as well or there will be hell to pay later," and it's the perfect trap because if Johnny doesn't introduce her she can feign that she's been egregiously offended and unappreciated by him. She's smirking because she's confident Johnny will introduce her into the discussion as his girl as she expects him to. She's also trying to play nice and look like the smiling, happy girlfriend that Johnny is head over heels for. He probably knows she expects him to do this because she's harrassed him to a million times over with similar encounters. Being introduced is very formal. She's playing with her status in relation to him. As far as she's concerned, Johnny is her arm candy and afterwards she gives him a smile albeit condescending to let him know she approves of his introduction of her and to reinforce that expectation and power imbalance. She's delusional.
author: Timberlyn Miles

comment:
This is a major issue in today's society, a man being victimized by a woman is seen as a joke. Just yesterday, one of my sales directors told me he got roofied by a woman thst was 10 years older than him, it seeme like he was making a joke but he was being dead serious, its that admitting that, as a man, you were victimized by a woman, is something difficult to say because its seen as a fucking joke. He was trying to be jokey about it, which was super sad, and was asking if I think he should do something about it, I said yes, he said he doesn't know what she gave him, told him to go get a toxicology test, find out wtf she slipped him then sue the living shit out of her.

The fact that this full grown man seemed embarrassed to even talk about it is terrible. The world needs to stop taking the woman's side JUST because she is a woman and understand that men deal with this terrible shit too.

author: Red X 4456

comment: The half smirk near the end from JD's side off could actually have had to do with Amber indeed tearing off his finger with the vodka bottle. It's fairly common for people to make these tiny smirks when they just can't believe that somehow so horrid actually happened to them. My father lived a life that few I would argue would be able to, and whenever he was looking back at the darker moments he actually did the same thing. Half smirk, only he would get very mad afterwards and tell us to go outside and play because obviously it wasn't something that we should ever be involved in. Through that we actually do have Amber Heard confessing to having both physically and mentally hurt Johnny Depp, so there's really nothing else to this story. She admitted it, several former friends of her spoke about about it as well, and all of Johnny Depp's ex-lovers came to his rescue so to speak too. The reason why Amber Heard hasn't been incarcerated yet? ‚Äî Favouritism. Well, that, and that she's a supposed woman. Now, I don't know just how experienced you are when it comes to that of body language, but to me she's not just guilty, she's showing it with proudness and carelessness for Johnny Depp and the hearing. I do however actually believe that Johnny might have had enough of her at some point (everyone has a boiling point after all), and it even appears according to herself that the security guards also could 't take anymore of her constant nagging and violent behaviour. Howbeit I do not believe that Johnny ever hit her, but that he deep down wanted to. This is of course just pure speculation from my side off, so do take it with a grain of salt.

It is a useful thing to do a bit of study on body language and non-verbal (and also apply a bit of empathy in the process) because then you can see that there is no victim in the AH video. The arrogant smiles (showing exactly what she thinks of JD), her carelessness and uninterested expressions ( not to mention the eating... nobody who has been a victim and suffering anxiety due to it would be eating in this situation as the OP said) do not belong to a victim, rather a sociopath trying to frame someone else

author: Kirann Kornat

comment:
Some of the questions they asked Amber I feel like are way too self-incriminating, especially the "did you hit Johnny Depp" question.  If I was a victim of abuse and I was asked that I would say a resounding YES because I would fight back if someone was hurting/abusing me.   I get why they asked her that question it was an easy (and cheap) jab at her to make her say she's guilty.   In the beginning of the video,  that lady who is asking questions was trying to trap Amber, she asked Amber if she is a domestic abuser and then asked if she understood the question.  Amber of course answered the first question and the lady was like, you don't understand my question? lol  That looked like another tactic to trap people, which is pretty scary.  Because what if it was anyone else in that situation and decided to answer yes to answer the follow up question instead of the first question of "did you commit this crime."  
Amber had a good lawyer, but I want to know who that lady who's asking Amber the questions is.  If that lady is Johnny's lawyer then I'm not surprised that he lost this case because she's a crappy lawyer to me (if she is a lawyer that is).   I feel like that lady lawyer's angle was to try and get Amber to admit guilt but I would think a better tactic would be to ask for the story first then poke holes in the story.  Trying to take cheap shots obviously  didn't help Johnny's case at all.  For whatever reason, Amber did seem unprepared, so her lawyer did lack in trying to get her head straight.
The hesitation from Johnny can probably play into him having to choose his words wisely due to lawyers trying to use a "trap tactic" in order to self-incriminate, but there's not much recordings on him so can't really tell much from that.  
This recording is just a small drop of an ocean so it doesn't really tell the whole picture.

author: MEC

comment: I've seen other comments about it, but wanted to make a similar one addressing Johnny smiling. As a survivor of DV myself I can confirm smiling as a defense mechanism. It's easier for your brain to handle trauma if it's looked at on a lighter side or even as a joke. Like "there's no way that was real. Haha." I remember when I would explain violent instances to my friends and how they would look at me almost in shock because I always described the incedent matter of factly, or with a laugh/joke at the end. It seems odd, but it's like people who laugh at death. We can only handle so much trama at one time so the brain does it's best with what it knows.
author: sarah cole

author: Lifeless web user

comment:
So I'm not a psychologist or anything like that  but I do that same half smirk that Johnny does when I talk about something traumatic or bad that happened to me, because in my head as I am trying to recollect and as time has passed, this memory seems so unreal and I baffle myself with the memory or even my actions which in my case are usually non existent due to shock. 

I will give a small example. I had a super abusive significant other and after we broke up a lot of my friends would ask me about very specific stories and I would do the smirk or even giggle and my friends would be shocked at this because, the story is no remotely funny but, I am not trying to make it funny. I'm remembering it almost like an outsider and asking myself why I didn't do anything. comment:
I'd suggest you read the current DSM. Not everyone's the same. She has hallmarks of PTSD. There's that hypervigilance in both the baseline and the deposition videos and also the grounding behaviour. Incongruency+spottiness of memories of traumatic events is pretty normal too for PTS sufferers. People in abusive relationships often wind up with PTSD and, speaking as someone who's been there, this is exactly what it looks like. Also, that recording speaks for itself. "I just got hit in the head with the corner of the F@(%!ng door". There's only one way that could have happened, short of her ripping the door from its hinges and chasing him around the house with it; he attempted to deprive her of the time-out she had every right to assert. Period.

The abuse is on his part right there because he had no right to decide for her if or when she could take a time-out from him. There's no "what about...". He shouldn't have done that in the first place and, had the police been present, his attempt to invade her space while she was trying to disengage from him would have led to a much more physical intervention long before his head had the opportunity to make contact with the door. As it stands, her ejecting him forcefully from her space is neither assault nor abuse in this context. Cornering someone and triggering their PTSD for purely sadistic reasons, on the other hand, is something I've seen plenty of and that really is abuse of the worst kind. And if you won't let her have her time-out when she needs it, what else are you trying to do to her?

Maybe there's more to this. I have no idea. I'm only commenting on what I've seen here. More than that, it simply makes me sad; especially considering that this is not the first time I've seen someone villified for the apparent crime of having PTSD.

comment: a similiar thing happened to my father and his wife (not my mom). everyone in the family knew she was an abuser and a generally bad person but my dad stayed with her anyway. my dad regularly came to my house at night because he couldnt stay home or because she got violent. unfortunately they had a baby and the situation just worsened. When my dad filed for divorce she accused him for physical and sexual assault, which is taken extremely seriously. towards the end of their relationship my dad recorded several incidents where it clearly shows that his wife abused him and even sometimes their 2 years old son. he had whatsapp chats, voice recordings and neighbor  testimonies confirming that they've seen the wife hitting the child in public. we all thought that her allegations wont mean anything and that my dad will get at least partial custody of his son. but somehow not only did she get full custody of the child, but also my dad will never be able to see his son (not until the boy is 18 and can decide for himself). when i helped him through the case, watched every deposition and read all the scripts, i was really astonished ... the overwhelming evidence against this woman, and the lack of any evidence on him. i couldnt understand how could they conclude that he was the abuser. some of the hearings were laughable, the woman would just start screaming and fake crying in an attempt to show the court how scared she is of him, to the point where he couldnt even be in his own hearing. usually am not the type to use race in an argument, i think its cheap and a hail mary attempt to salvage a lost argument. but if u look at my name u can figure out am middle eastern, and so is my dad ofc. I have no choice left but to think thats the reason he lost his case, because he is an ARAB and a MAN, while she is a European woman. but hey what do i know, i just feel bad for my dad.

author: Milly Day

comment:
Logan,
I would like to offer a different take on many of the Amber Heard deposition readings. 
1. The first conflicted nod (misaligned communication) did not just follow the question ‚ÄúDid you commit an act of domestic violence against Johnny Depp?‚Äù After Heard‚Äôs attorney interrupted, the deposing lawyer asked ‚Äúdid you understand my question?‚Äù I believe Heard was nodding yes to that, then answering ‚ÄúNo‚Äù to the question of having committed domestic violence [DV] on that date.
2. 2nd question. Part of reading body language is figuring out what‚Äôs going on in the person‚Äôs head. I believe some of her non-verbal language is an on-going reaction to her internal dialogue. Notice that the deposing lawyer has changed tack. This question changes from ‚Äúdid you commit DV on this date...‚Äù to ‚Äúis it your testimony that you NEVER committed ANY act of what is considered DV...?‚Äù Here you can see Heard register the new question &  process the implications. Her head shakes ‚Äòno‚Äô and the words come out parsed into smaller blocks as she takes in the enormity of ‚Äúdid you ever‚Äù vs. ‚Äúdid this happen on said date.‚Äù Her adjustment verbally moved from ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt commit DV‚Äù to ‚ÄúI did my best... to defend myself‚Ä¶ And not... not... not get seriously hurt‚Ä¶ And not become a doormat... to whom this happened to.‚Äù And as she says that, each pause is assessment & reflection that seems to say ‚Äúwhen he hit me, did I hit him back or just defend? Were MY actions justifiable or did I go beyond?‚Äù Her face never changes from concern to ‚Äôoops‚Äô or gloating. It remains consistent rather than revealing an internal epiphany. I see her reaction as that of someone who understands the social implications of women getting beaten and not having recourse because they are not believed. But, also knowledge that even though women are generally weaker, they will be punished more severely for crossing the line that men cross so casually. I also think that these aren‚Äôt two strikes against Amber, as you said.
3. 3rd question. Did you tell Johnny you beat him? It‚Äôs a poorly phrased question with no sensible segue from prior questions. You‚Äôve already noted that she was disoriented prior to this and she clearly does not follow the shift from ‚Äúdid you hit him‚Äù to ‚Äúdid you TELL Johnny you hit him.‚Äù It makes sense that questioning if she told him she hit him would be confusing, especially after she just said she has been defending herself against his beatings... many times. The attorney cuts her off claiming the answer as non-responsive. That‚Äôs because she is not answering the new question. Hasn‚Äôt realized the context has changed. She is still clarifying (poorly) that she was acting in defense. 
4. ‚ÄúJohnny and I.‚Äù Point 1: having not yet seen the later eating incident, I will say that people are comfortable giving a short answer while chewing. Point 2: going back to the idea that she physically respond to her own thoughts, the ‚ÄúNo‚Äù shake of the head could have been in response to her own statement of trying to get away from Johnny; ‚Äúno, it wasn‚Äôt possible to escape.‚Äù Baseline Observation: earlier you mentioned her baseline as eyes that constantly roam over the room (especially when she‚Äôs uncomfortable with questioning). Her response is so visceral here that she‚Äôs become laser focused on what‚Äôs in front of her. 
5. Of course I hit him, duh. You asked ‚Äúif this were in any other situation would you believe it?‚Äù No. But, abuse situations are very particular. If her allegations are true, she would do anything to back him up enough to close the door. And even then it would probably only give a short respite. Even though you say this answer is rehearsed. I contend that a moment ago (answer 4), she had laser focus, but by this she has returned to the roaming eyes baseline and stumbling over her words. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs as rehearsed as it looked on prior viewings. And she backs it up with a very clear non-verbal hand motion to push someone away. In a tussle that push could‚Äôve turned into an accidental hit. Clarification after listening to Q6: The next question makes it clear that this was not her hitting him with her hand, but with the door. That makes even more sense when you‚Äôre trying to shut the door and there‚Äôs a body blocking the way. It was an unintentional consequence of the moment.
6. I‚Äôm bored. All too frequently, the police and reporters get upset because abused women don‚Äôt respond the way they think women should. The women are excoriated for being either overly emotional or affectless. Each resulting in an accusation¬†of faking it. Whether it‚Äôs rape or physical abuse, many women realize the cards are stacked against them and adopt this flat affect of ‚Äúyou won‚Äôt believe me anyway.‚Äù Other times, that affect is shock. Plus, she‚Äôs beginning to see where the lawyer is going. So, you are right, she DOES NOT want to be here.
7. Did you say you didn‚Äôt intend to hit him? Depositions are high stress environments. She has already borne through a barrage of questions and emotions. At this point she could very well be reliving the moment through the fog of memory and just didn‚Äôt hear the exact words on the tape. It might not look good to the casual viewer, but this happens a lot.
8. Misrepresentation by deposing lawyer. Heard‚Äôs response corroborates everything I said earlier about defending against an abuser and how a door can be slammed in the heart of the moment. Yes she did realize she had made a mistake by losing focus, not by misstating. Her lawyer should inform her she has the right to request the tape be replayed.
9. The mouthful pause. As stated earlier. An in depth answer can‚Äôt be talked through as easily. She shouldn‚Äôt be eating, but this is a legitimate moment of having a lot to say and not wanting to do it while masticating. 
10. The whisper. Mock her for it, if you must. But her lawyer is right. These whispers are distracting & annoying. Consider though that she didn‚Äôt have the tantrum that you re-enacted. Her response was to let them say what was needed before she finished. And waiting through one whisper is not a delay tactic.
11. Asked and answered. You are 100% correct. This looks bad. It‚Äôs why lawyers ask yes/no questions. To get you to say something incriminating. Her lawyer‚Äôs job is to get her explanation on cross examination. If he were a better lawyer, he‚Äôd instruct her to answer yes or no & stop telling her to answer however she wants.
12. Johnny Depp section: how much baseline tape did you watch for Depp? A. He does that smile a few times. Are we right to so quickly discount duper‚Äôs delight? B. I think he does throw in lots of excess details. He‚Äôs just more smooth about it. C. Mellow. I knew a guy in the 70‚Äôs who won most of his court cases by taking a quaalude beforehand. The opposing attorneys could never rattle him as he was unshakeable in his demeanor & delivery. D. Not mentioned in your video, but worth noting about both parties; abusers are incredibly charming and winsome when on display. They don‚Äôt present in public as the monsters they are.

comment:
23:53 - The difference between Amber Heard's details and Johnny Depp's details go deeper than that. It's not merely that Amber adds details that "don't need to be there" - she adds and emphasises details that shift the focus away from the facts of the case, and towards her victimhood and/or self-righteousness. 

This is the primary difference between the abuser's "side of the story" vs the victim's. See, I would actually argue that Amber doesn't actually give detailed accounts at all - most of her details are vague. She doesn't remember exactly how things happened, who was there, what exactly Johnny did or how exactly she responded. Note that by the end of that long-winded explanation she still has no answer for the lawyer's question (Did you hit Johnny with a closed fist, yes or no?) But what she *does* vividly recount is the way she *felt* justified at the time because of the perceived threat to her sister's wellbeing, and she repeats this three or four times with unbridled conviction so that the audience can be sure to sympathise with her. It's a classic trick to emotionally manipulate the audience into feeling sorry for you. 

Real victims, on the other hand, usually want the truth to be judged for what it is, and for their own vindication to feel justly earned. They will recount in detail the *facts* of the case - who was where, what was said, what exactly happened. This is the contrast we see in Johnny Depp's vs Amber Heard's testimony. Real victims are able to deliver details about context, facts, exact words, exact actions, because they know that these details vindicate them. Fake victims are - at least subconsciously - aware of how bad their actions would look in full context, so they flub away as much of it as they can and keep the focus on the authenticity of their *emotional response,* and hope nobody notices the difference.

Side note: If any of you want to read more about this, check out Issendai's "Down the rabbit hole" blog about the way abusive parents spin their fake victim narratives on Estranged Parents forums. Warning: if you are in or have just managed to escape an abusive familial situation, some of the articles may hit quite close to home for you.

comment: I'm in AP psych, so I'm obviously not a professional or anything, but one of the first things that we learn is that when people lie usually they only recall in a two dimensional way what they supposedly saw or heard. They do not include things like what they smelled, tasted, or the space around them. Notice how Amber was just like that, a straight story of what Johnny did to her. While Johnny's story included details, recalling exactly where he was sitting, where his arm was placed, the kind of chair he was sitting on (a marble chair), and even the little detail of what he calls the finger that got hit. It includes so much sensory information. That's just something I noticed as someone in psych but again I'm only in high school and I could be wrong.

author: Crimson Matron

comment:
I'm guessing that Johnny Depp is a covert narcissist and that Amber may be sociopathic.  They abused each other but both deny it.
If she was more abused though (which I think may be likely when Johnny was drinking)... I wouldn't want to be in court to defend myself again either and be retraumatized over and over by reliving the abusive relationship...as lawyers make the same kinds of accusations that the abuser did in harsh tones.   CPTSD of victims CAN look like how Amber is acting...flustered, confused, brain fog, stress, distracted, disinterested, trying to escape mentally.  Real victims are NOT always sure they were being abused because of the emotional and mental manipulations by the abuser that make them think it's their own fault.  So if you aren't confident (many abused people aren't), you wouldn't show a lot of conviction about the messy relationship being all the abuser's fault. She knows she also has to stay calm in court but these issues could trigger an outburst so she knows she can't get passionate or reactive to all these triggers.

comment:
I was abused as a child then I was abused in a long term relationship. I have PTSD and anxiety from the violence. My ex was handsome, had a hero complex and most likely a sociopath that without effort or remorse made himself look like a victim. In private he was very abusive, aggressive, and threatening. Being abused and gaslighted. I believed, and he proved to me many times, that he could make anyone believe that I was the aggressor even with my family and friends. I didn't seem credible to anyone because I was already defeated. I used too many details and people picked me apart.
If she is already mentally defeated: 
I see the eating and nonchalant attitude as stuffing down anxiety and mental self protection against being rejected because she is already self defeated. 
I see that she thinks if she admits to hitting that she will be preseived as the monster that hit the beloved. 
I see the her anger rise when speaking of protecting her sister. This shows that she has 0 self esteem to defend herself but will fight to protect her loved one.
I see her confidence in public with him as her trying to present herself with dignity because in public an abuser will usually not show any aggression in public and it is the time where the abused can feel some personal strength and put a wall up so they don't completely fall apart in front of others. I also believe it is a gesture saying  "you haven't broken me yet" in a visceral way. Although you are very broken.
I do believe the relationship revved up to a level of abuse most likely became mutual
I see Depp's as the truth in that recollection of time but that doesn't speak to what happened before or after she threw the bottles at him.
I'm very curious to see what you think about my interpretation of what may be the case.

author: HTNPSullivan

comment:
Wow, this guy is such a poor reader of body language. Let me count the ways... 

Regarding the first observation during the deposition. She nods "yes" to "do you understand the question?," and is actually saying "no" in answer to the question itself!, as in "No, I didn't physically abuse him." So, that's a big miss by this presenter.  

Regarding the "mouth shrugs" - I don't think she's trying to "come up with a story," I think she's trying to find the right words -- as in, "yes there were physical confrontations, but I wasn't the aggressor, i was trying to protect myself." My sense is that this person isn't terribly bright or articulate and under pressure, even if what she's saying is truthful, she doesn't have confidence in her ability to convince other people, that she already feels like people don't believe her. 

About eating -- she's eating because she's nervous. Good God, that's such a common thing, how can this guy misinterpret it? Granted, it's WEIRD to eat during a deposition, but it's the equivalent of biting your nails. Good old Freud would tell you it's a throwback to being a baby and needing to put something in your mouth when you're anxious, i.e. your mother's breast (thus all the "oral fixation" theories about why people smoke or overeat).  

Also, this is important --  I was in a (verbal/psychologically) abusive relationship for 11 years. Very bad shit happens to your self-image and confidence when you are abused over time. Like shame. Especially when the abuser is well liked, and therefore people don't believe you when you make the rare attempt to describe what's going on behind closed doors. I cannot begin to tell you how lame I sounded the few times I tried to explain how my ex chipped away at me on a daily basis. He was very talented at constant and classic "gaslighting." 

If you had told me I would someday let someone with a highschool education, a "recovering" alcoholic who worked in a convenience store/cleaned offices at night/took care of a disabled man part-time -- despite being very intelligent, attractive,  articulate and able-bodied (versus my 30 years as a reporter and teacher, with a degree from an ivy league university, and a published photographer, and a Garden Master for a community garden I built in 2008) make me feel like dirt under his shoes, I would have laughed at you. But narcissists are very good at finding the places where you are NOT confident and really ripping away at those wounds until you feel like you are stupid and helpless. This is how they feel better about themselves.

As for the time she ate something (again, that's nerves and frustration) and she takes time to chew - that's not "what a pause!," she just that second put the friggin food in her mouth. Nobody but a two-year old would attempt to talk right after putting something in her mouth. Duh. 

And as for avoiding the "yes or no" question, f*ck the person asking it. You don't answer a "yes or no" question about punching someone. That's like, "Yes or no," have you stopped beating your wife?" when you never hit your wife in the first place. I agree with her counsel - answer the way you want to. "Yes or no" is a bullying tactic. 

And finally, Johnny Depp's body language while being interviewed in Japan may or may have had more to do with how much he had to drink by that time of the day, or how wasted he was the night before. Anyone who's known a chronic drinker/drug-abuser, which even Depp would say he is, should recognize the body language. Please also bear in mind what a good actor he is in his films. He certainly could fake sincerity during a deposition, and he's at an advantage because he's much better known and loved by movie goers than Amber. 

This is a terrible, terrible analysis. And if you think I am biased because I was abused (Mr. Wrong is now long gone -- after my having a stress induced heart attack and surgery, and finally finding my courage. He left pre-pandemic lockdown, thank God!), let me say this -- previous to watching this video, I believed Amber was a money-grabbing, publicity-seeking liar. I'd read some pretty negative stuff about her, and the few quotes from her I read sounded fishy. But watching this actually changed my mind!

 I don't know this guy's background, but he doesn't seem to understand basic human nature, nevermind body language.

comment:
This was pretty awful.
Her looking around the room all the time isn't ADHD or drugs? She's been on a Provigil script since her early twenties. Relevant provigil side effects: nervousness, anxiety, agitation, dry mouth You should do your homework on your victims before victim blaming in your videos.
You point out her answering a question while eating and the first instance she has the food in her mouth longer before the question is even asked than second time when the question is asked simultaneous to the food reaching her cheak, yet you don't point the timing out. Next video, you shovel food in your face while talking, see what happens.
You ask "Why is she so disinterested in being there if she's the victim?" Clearly you have no understanding of her position and zero empathy .  They are interogating her and their sole role is to try to incriminate her, not to support her. I was in a situation just like hers, where I was trying to escape behind a door while be attacked, and I was railroaded and victimized by the justice department because the attacker fell and hurt themselves, and after hurting themselves they continued to hurl themselves at the door, and like Johnny Depp they were A) on drugs at the time of the attack and B) calm and collected when they gave their wholly bogus statement to the police, and then the officer was calm and non-expressive when he gave his misrepresentation of my statement to the court. Liars can be very calm and non expressive, especially under the influence or when they have no emotional investment in the lie because they know from their own experience they will get away with it. The police force this cop was on blew up a guys house to catch one shoplifter and got away with it, then when laws were passed in Colorado to make police accountable the city council of that town said "Nah, we won't make them accountable, state laws don't apply to us"...but that's another story. Johnny Depp is a life long drug user, his reactions and mannerisms are drug induced. You introduce a public appearance at the end and completely misread it: Johnny is looking down because A) everyone around him is five foot tall  B) he has ADHD. Amber has to look down too, but you ignore that.

comment:
I've known of several girlfriends amongst friends that have caused otherwise calm guys to get angry and lash out. Not by hitting the girlfriend, these are decent people, but usually at inanimate objects or just extreme anger and shouting. 

Sadly some people just aren't suited to each other, and that's always apparent when people can have a string of perfectly normal relationships, yet can fall into one and it can literally alter the way a person reacts. 

Amber is a drama queen, and knows how to trigger guys, and importantly, cares to when it suits her. The fact Depp was married for, what, nearly two decades and his ex has never claimed he was violent says a lot. I've no doubt Depp was pushed to be more angry than any of his past girlfriends or wife ever experienced makes sense because of what Amber does, and is capable of. 

The truth will be revealed when she comes out and confesses a future boyfriend or husband is violent! I've no doubt their relationship was genuine in many respects, but I'm convinced, probably like most, that he was as much a means to advance her career as he was a partner. 

She absolutely will trigger a future partner; this won't be the last time she claims someone's been violent towards her. The fact she punched a boyfriend/husband says a lot. Punching a partner is outright unacceptable irrespective of gender. I don't care about Depp; I'm not defending a star who I'm a fan of. 

Amber is big trouble, and she needs to be extremely careful and a lot more wiser about who she's with, and certainly who she marries in future. She used her false domestic violence claim now; worse still, she's now likely to not be believed if she's ever unfortunate enough to experience it for real. Stupid, stupid girl.

comment:
At 05:15 Amber Heard has been asked a question that was interrupted for some lawyer stuff, then she is asked if she understands what the questioner has asked, to which she answers with a nod and then answers the initial question with a verbal "no".   I do not see why our host is unable to understand this simple and common combination of verbal and nonverbal communication.  He even says that it is "two distinct communication devices that are used one right after the other, rather than at the same time."  Yet he fails to consider that they might be two separate communications, answering the two separate questions she has been asked.  This is something that I consider painfully obvious, all that is required is to watch the video while listening to the audio. 

     At this point, I thought that there was little point in my watching the rest of the video.  I thought that there was no way the host could regain my confidence in their ability or lack of bias, and I was wrong.  Other than that gaff at the start, the worst thing I could say is that the host might not have been charitable enough when assessing Ms. Heard's reaction to some confusingly framed questions.  But that is not a real complaint, that would just be me trying to find falt in order to support a cherished conclusion.  Seriously, I saw no flaw in anything else, including his choice of how to read her reaction to the questioning. 

     This all made me rewatch the first part of the video to reassess, however, I still see it the same way, just as plain as day.   Amber Heard is asked two questions, the initial question about domestic violence, and the second question about whether or not she understood the first question.  She answered the second, and more chronologically immediate question. first, with a nod.  Then she answered the initial question with a simple verbal "no".
