comment:
Her bored, defiant behavior (which, btw, wasn't at ALL hidden and was loudly broadcasting an intended message) could have been because she was being questioned by Depp's lawyer to make her look guilty. It could easily be a passive aggressive move expressing contempt for having to, once again, defend herself.  I don't know if that is what is going on but I don't think this guy interpreting her actions has thought about all the possibilities. He definitely isn't analyzing her body language objectively. It seems he had made up his mind about her from the beginning.

Her "defensive move", for example, could have been to ward off the perceived attack she felt she was under by Depp's lawyer and all the other people who don't believe her. She could have been trying to push a memory away -one of Depp arguing that she clocked him with a closed fist. Did she or didn't she? I don't know. But those defensive moves don't automatically equate to lying.

Her long pause while she chewed could have been to, yes, collect her thoughts because she didn't want to say, "Yes, I've hit him." when that statement doesn't present the truth. The truth could easily have been, "Yes, I've hit him... once, when he was attacking me and my sister on a stair landing and he was about to push her down the stairs for protecting me." If that's the truth, who could blame her for wanting to say it and NOT have her mouth full of food?! Again, I don't know if that's the truth but I don't think this guy knows it, either -especially because she chewed her food first before answering it.

comment: I have been a 911 dispatcher for a decade and have taken countless calls for reports of domestic abuse. To anyone saying that a man can't be a victim, I beg to differ. ANYONE can be a victim. Man, woman, child, elderly, rich, poor, powerful, and those incapable of advocating for themselves. I have taken calls for stabbings, shootings, physical assaults, and emotional abuse where men are absolutely the victim. Being a woman doesn't negate that anyone is capable of being a truly heinous person. I'm not publicly taking sides on this situation. I'm just telling you what I know. Also, if you or anyone you know is need of help, please reach out to the police for assistance or call the national domestic abuse hotline 1-800-799-7233. Stay safe.

comment:
Okay so I tried to post this and it was too long but I have to get this out there. 

(Sorry guys! Please don't hate on me- but as a person who genuinely struggles with nonverbal miscommunications while everyone is just so quick to jump on bandwagons and assumptions and stuff it's damaging. really damaging. and it's a legit struggle for me. Nonverbals really don't always have to show what a person is thinking or how they feel. at least for me it really doesn't and I always get insulted when people assume I just want to write this for anyone else out there who is like me and has been misjudged or just idk what even to call it. People just love to make assumptions and idk if Amber really is acting I want to advocate for everyone who actually are being genuine and people want to just assume because they really don't understand..I LOVE Johnny Depp. Hands down team Johnny. So please don't come for me. ).

I also trip over my words and look around when I'm speaking. It helps us think because the barrier between the connection of thought and the actual product of the words and emotions aren't always matching. It's a disconnect. Like her base line is my base line. Doesn't mean she's a liar because of it. She's nervous. Naturally very nervous which means she's been through some shit. 

Looking around the room when someone talks to you also shows anxiety. The disconnect between the yes and no thing, I do that too. 

I do think this is a different situation but that's because if she is like me she definitely hit him. there's no way- she's very emotional, probably can't collect her thoughts, probably a very anxious and nervous person in general daily life. 

Shrugging shows neutrality in my opinion. Like "oh yeah well I don't really have an opinion about it/don't think about it too much" DOES NOT MEAN she's manipulating or anything. Actually it's a very strong defense when people get particular accusatory tones. 

That female Lawyer tone is SO accusatory. Let's look at nonverbal sure but let's look at WHY she would act nonverbally like that. 1. That ladies tone even triggers me. I want to smack her because it's a type of tone that's like "uh huh sure you definitely are guilty of hurting Johnny Depp" without being actually neutral. You can hear it in her voice with the way that lady said "YoU DoN'T UnDeRsTaNd ThE QuEsTiOn?"  LIKE WOMAN TO WOMAN WHAT ARE YOU DOING FEMALE LAWYER. CHECK YOURSELF. 

Let's talk about the mouth. "Mouth Shrugs" ok. Maybe she is actually surprising emotions. I do that. I will get a rise or a sudden spike  in my emotions which then causes them to make my eyes tears up and my lip pout. What do I always do? I shrug with my mouth because I don't want to make a scene. A way to detach and try to control the emotions.  Trying to remember something that caused any kind of emotion causes that. Sometimes tears don't even fill my eyes. My lip just quivers. 

THE FOOD? omg. I have been abused all of my life. Yes, while what you're saying about the food here could be true for her try to picture it yourself. (NOT FOR AMBER JUST FOR A DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVE) Let's say you went through something traumatic- which myself and many other women and men have and again everyone is different- you had to deal with it how ever many years ago. Then it goes to court and it's a LONG process for that to happen. You finally have to relive all of your trauma. Idk about others. But for me- When I went through that.  didn't eat properly and couldn't sleep until that date. In the interview there were snacks. It's a comfort thing because it's traumatic to even step foot in the same place as your potential abuser. I definitely nibbled because it's a nervous habit and nothing at all like what could be going on here. 

also. DO YOU KNOW HOW HARD IT IS TO RECOUNT EVENTS VERBATIUM AFTER YEARAS OF NOT NEEDING TO? MEMORY. it kinda can do this thing where it rewrites your memories...
author: Kat's Korner

comment:
I remember some good details 30 years ago when I was 4 or 5, how my parents fights, how they scratch and hit each other. my father ended up with big scratches on his belly, my mom's head swollen and she was crying. the other time I saw dinner plates flying from dinner table to the TV, it's glass monitor broken. I remember when my dad met his mistress, he went with me to see her and we went to the mall, and met coincidently to his colleague, him asking my father, "are they your wife and daughter ?" or are you with your family.. something like that. I was about to say no, she is not my mom. but dad interrupt me.
I remember they took me to the mistress house. I left alone in the living room, she bought me toys (piano toys and comic books, my mom threw them all later on) so I played alone.

before they officially divorced, dad asked me if I want to live with him. I was the closest child to him, I am middle child of 3. and now I really feel betrayed. no one knew what happened to me when I was child. I told everyone when I was 30 or late 20s. no one knew that, nor my mom or my siblings. because mom said, when I was in middle school dad said to her (years after divorced dad visited once in while), I was not like I used to be, I was not that close to dad anymore, not clinging to him anymore, I shut him off,  I was like different person (because I already felt betrayed at that time). I never knew dad thought like that to me, so I told mom everything. as much as I could remember.

I am not a victim of domestic abuse, I only witnessed the process how my parents divorced. and I could remember, I say, quite good detail. I can remember it like watching tv show, over and over again. even when I don't want to remember. how can a victim forgot about what happened and TRY to recollecting?

It's sad because she slandered his name when in actuality, she's the abuser, she's the real monster.

comment:
I totally understand what JD is doing when talking about what happened.  I used to do the same thing.  I always tried to relay my experience to others in a way I thought that they would be more comfortable,  if that makes sense.  I didn't want to make others uncomfortable with my pain and trauma. I dissociate when I talk about it like it's not a big deal or make light of it,  but its always in my effort to make sure I'm not making them feel uncomfortable or feel bad for me.
Edit:  Also,  I just realized the incident she's referring to at around 12:32 and later,  she's bold face lying.  JD was the one who was trying to get away from her by locking himself in the bathroom,  and SHE is the one trying to get in.  She pushes the bathroom door open,  he tries to keep her out by pushing the door back in her direction the door then goes over her toes,  he bends down to check on her toes and she slams the door into his head,  and then punches him in the face. 
Source: It's all in the audio they record for their counseling sessions. *In all her own words* .
Sorry this is so long :-(

comment:
First off, I also don't think she is totally innocent and that some of her appearance or behavior is contradictory to her words, BUT I like to be fair and I do think that some things she does that you point out, are explainable in a different way. For one thing, I think her whole cool and kind of bored impression can also be grounded on being fed up with the whole thing (the trial and attention and all) and yes, she surely doesn't like doing the questioning but that doesn't mean she is (all) guilty does it? 
Also, there is this thing a lot of people often disinterpret on people, it's when people seem to not care or play cool and arrogant and actually they are unsure and maybe not fine with themselves- which could still point to a certain guilt on her side but it could also not do. But to be fair here again, I have to say that seeing more clips of her,  I'd say, in her case, she probably is somewhat arrogant and selfrighteous but let us still not forget that arrogant appearance actually often does *not* mean that the person doesn't care!
To the scene on the red carpet- I do get dominant vibes from her but in no way can one judge from this scene that she is bad to him through out the whole relationship. Also let us not forget that Johnny mostly appears rather shy or calm in public and not exactly extroverted. And, she is taller than him and also wears high heels so it would be difficult for her to not look down on him. XD I only get some tension vibes here which can be grounded on quarrel they had before but that doesn't have to mean it was physical.
Frankly, I just don't think you should state that she or he *must* be guilty, personally I think it is the most plausible that they both were violent against each other and in the end there is a court and a judgement for a reason.
author: Jul H

comment: Side note, that boredom/checking out reaction is not an anomaly for domestic violence victims during the hearing. At that point in the process many victims have would been questioned thousands of times and it becomes exhausting. Additionally, disassociating/depersonalization is a common defense mechanism in victims of trauma. This can result in the victim appearing bored and not caring. (In regards to Amber, this is not the case. She was genuinely bored and not caring.)

comment: Domestic abuse victims as victims of trauma. Do not give off the same ‚Äútells‚Äù as someone who has not experienced complex trauma. There is a lot of guilt and shame that the victims feel which is why this type of abuse is so horrible. Take for example children of abusive parents who grow up blaming themselves. We can guess what her body language might be saying but this is ambiguous as she may be re-experiencing past trauma whilst she is talking about it. There are so many reasons for her body language to be off. People behave differently under pressure or when being watched.  NO ONE knows what happened in their relationship. The best thing we can do is not try to speculate on the ‚Äútruth‚Äù but to give them both the space to gain closure and heal from what sounds like a really fucked up relationship. Have some empathy.
author: Hester Ormrod

author: Francesmilly

comment:
I honestly think that you were a little critical of the defensive responses she was giving. 

First of all, I want to clarify that I don't know much about this situation and I definitely find some of her affect, particularly the lack of caring she is showing here and the mouth-full pauses, kinda sus. 

But also, I am looking at this from a victim's advocate perspective. I have a background as a legal advocate for victims of domestic violence, SA, and human trafficking. It is not uncommon for victim-survivors to have a defensive reaction when pressed about these circumstances. This is largely because of the stigma surrounding being a victim and the way that the legal system can treat victims.

You point out her defensive 'palms-out' response when she is being asked about the recordjng in which she admits to hitting Johnny with a door. Her response is that yes, she did, but it was because she was in a situation where he was trying to break into a room she was trying to hide in, and she feared for her imminant safety. The attorney who was addressing her very clearly wanted her to answer with no context, and simply say "yeah I hit Johnny with a door." Which ultimately is a statement that without context, creates a narrative that she was abusive towards him, instead of the other way around. She is defending her statement that she was doing this and self-defense, from an attorney who was asking a question that is designed to cast doubt on whether or not she was telling the truth about her victimhood.

Another point that you reference is around the 18:30 mark, where instead of directly answering the attorney's question about whether or not she has hit Johnny Depp with a closed fist, she tells a story leading up to it. Again, I think that this is similar to the situation above, where this attorney is asking questions that specifically are designed to cast out onto whether or not she is a victim. I think that anyone in that circumstance would feel defensive. Sometimes, defensiveness isn't because of guilt, it's because it's what you've had to do to survive and get this far. In fact, if she wasn't defensive about the circumstances of those questions, I would find it a lot more suspicious.

I've been in many courtrooms with victims of domestic violence, as a supporting advocate. And I will definitely say that there are parts of this deposition that align with what I have seen from victims of these types of crimes. I will also say that there are some things that she does in this deposition that definitely DON'T align. 

If I had to make a complete guess, as an outsider just solely watching this deposition, my conclusion would be that she is telling the truth about being the victim here. But, I also get the sense that she also had abusive tendencies or behaviors that she doesn't want people knowing about. But of course, I really want to underline, that even with my experience, there is no way that I can make that claim with 100% certainty. If is entirely a hunch based on my experience, observation, and opinion.

I love your content, and I really love the way that you approach these things in a very non-biased way. But I also feel that there may have been some missed nuance in the way that these types of cases present themselves, especially in the legal system.

**Edited for typos

comment:
Very biased delivery. I mean, she shows some signs of what you are describing, but only in like 20% of your statements. 80% are non-issues.
From your analysis, you would conclude she's guilty, even when we would switch the facts in this video to show she is innocent. Like... You first decided she is guilty and then you interpret her behavior with that result. "Oh, she thinks before she speaks? She must be guilty. Surely she is creating a lie instead of trying to remember." You judge every "insignificant behavior" like that. While at the same time missing/ignoring the logical inconsistencies in her statements, which point to her guilt more objectively. After seeing this video, I am very glad "feeling shamans" are not an accepted method to prove guilt or innocence.
Not to mentions you have trouble following what is going on in the video. Which is surprising, since the video is edited. Like she gets 2 questions at the same time: "did you commit domestic violence" followed by "do you understand the question". And she replies to both - first she nods as in "yes, I understand the question" and then answers "No, I did not commit domestic violence" - which you seem to be very confused by; or she whispers and they tell her she should not whisper - and you flip it like she's complaining that there is whispering in the room - that only happened in your head. Maybe you were very emotional while doing this video.

Regarding the eating-thing. I do agree with people who say that they probably gave her food to buy her time to think out answers. You can see it a few times when she conveniently takes a bite just as she is asked a question.
That aside though, I think it works to her disadvantage in general here. As a survivor of domestic violence myself, I know for a fact that there is no way I could be eating or snacking while discussing what I have been through - and this despite the fact that I am an emotional eater and use food to self-soothe. If I am put in a position to recall and re-tell my experience, my emotional response would be so strong that I actually lose my appetite, again; despite being an emotional eater. The fact that she can sit there and casually snack while talking about this tells me a lot already.

Also just looking at her face, I feel like she has those moments when she suddenly remembers "Oh, right, I'm supposed to look sad" and then she tries to make a sad face before going back to just looking bored. Neither does she ever look scared. I don't know if Johnny is actually present during these interrogations, but even if he wasn't, I feel like she would have an emotional response to having to re-live these experiences through these interrogations. It has been years since I left my ex-husband, and I would say that I have "recovered" quite well since then, but if I had to talk about what happened, I still get an emotional response from it and I can still feel the fear that I felt while going through these experiences, even all these years later. The fact that she can sit there and look bored while talking about something that was supposedly really traumatizing, again, speaks volumes. And don't even get me started on her smirking..

Johnny comes off as a lot more genuine to me. Yes, he smiles and laughs while talking as well, but I don't get the feeling that it comes from a place of him actually thinking it's funny or that he's winning and got everyone fooled (like Amber's smirk does). In his case, it feels more like he's trying to wrap his mind around the absurdity of everything she's done, like "I can't believe this actually happened and I can't believe it happened to Me". I also think it might be a nervous response. When I went through a traumatic event many years ago, I was laughing and cracking jokes right after it happened. It wasn't because I thought it was funny (quite the opposite), but I think a reaction to the shock and a way of trying to protect myself from the trauma. Once it actually sunk in what had happened, is when I had the "normal" response that someone would expect from a traumatic event (crying and depression). I think that is what was happening with Johnny in this interrogation; it was a nervous response and a way to distance himself from the trauma of what he has been through. And that is entirely different from the smirking coming from Amber through this; she is clearly not reacting to trauma. Nothing about her behaviour would suggest that to me.

Lastly, the clip of the two of them together. I have been noticing in a lot of photos of the two of them together that Johnny has that blank hollow look in his eyes when next to her, whereas her stance next to him really suggests that she is the dominant one in the relationship. She definitely doesn't look like someone who is afraid of her husband, not even a little bit. I think in this clip to, I feel like when he looks at her, he looks at her for confirmation. It's not like someone looking at the person they love, it feels more like he is seeking her approval. If he indeed was the abuser, he wouldn't look at her like that because he wouldn't need her approval for anything. And if she was as terrified of him as she claims, she would be shrunk over next to him, she wouldn't stand tall and confident, like she does.

That got long.. Kudos to anyone who made it through my long rant, haha. She just angers me so much.. Once I get started, I can't stop..

comment: Possible adhd? If she's undiagnosed, these are typical behaviors. As someone with adhd i can tell you that eating, especially sugary snacky foods, is a way to seek dopamine which my brain is severely lacking. If you put me in a sterile room for hours on end and spoke to me with monotone, quiet voices, with unclear and overlapping questions, I don't care what has happened to me I will be acting exactly like this. I'm not saying she's not lying but if she is neuro divergent, comparing her in your head to a neurotypical model could be skewing your findings. Just something to think about!

I want to ask a question, at 5:22 - the part where she shakes her head yes, and then says no to the question of domestic violence. Could she be answering the question that the prosecutor asked first, meaning the prosecutor asks her, "Do you understand what I am asking you?" It looks to me she's nodding her head that yes she understands, and then answer the question of domestic abuse with no. And then she comes back and says, "Yes, I understand." 
Am I completely off on that? Obviously she has admitted to hitting him multiple times, so am not asking it in defense of her, just for my own edification on the body reading. **Edited to say, you mention that she is on trial for alleged assault at 10:00 - no, she's just a witness for the defense in this case. This is not a criminal court procedure, nor is she on trial. If you listen closely to her lawyer, she's being told that her alleged abuse is irrelevant to the proceedings for this court case.  If we're going to look at body language, it would be helpful to be correct on what the deposition is. I think if it was a criminal procedure and she was on trial, it would be completely different.

comment:
To be fair, to answer your question: "why would she be so apparently disinterested in being there if she's a victim," obviously she is not the mousey victim here and I strongly believe she's the perpetrator of most if not all of the abuse and violence here, but let's pretend like in Amber's head that she's completely innocent and all the accusations against her are misunderstandings or outright lies. 
Everyone in the room aside from her lawyer seems to be very visibly in belief that she is lying or holding something back, that she has acted violently upon Johnny multiple times. If she's innocent then this is a lie or a misrepresentation, and if you're a victim it's got to be incredibly tiring and frustrating and annoying to be constantly having to prove yourself as the victim, and to be asked the same questions multiple times, with less patience for the answer every time. She's clearly not wanting to be there for a different reason but I can imagine that for another person who is actually a victim, being in this situation would make you fed up, probably.

comment: I'm not defending her or even commenting on this particular situation. Men can definitely be abused and deserve justice.  Its interesting to me the assumptions behind body language in response to trauma, I think I'd talk about the abuse that happened to me in a bored way and look uncomfortable as hell because it's simply uncomfortable to hear it. I'd definitely smirk at being accused otherwise, too. Abuse changes the way you present yourself. If I treat it like it's boring then it's less upsetting and triggering mentally and I'd laugh at someone trying to accuse me otherwise. I wonder, in general, not in this case particularly, if the weird way abuse victims respond to trauma is taken into consideration?

comment:
Ah jeez.  The whole body language commentary on the two as a couple is incredibly reaching - most, if not all, of the contrasts you see lie directly with the fact that a) Depp is a self described hermit, uncomfortable with the pomp and attention of "red carpet" events - this is LONG established; and b) even when sober (and there's no basis to suggest he is sober here either), because Depp has abused drugs and alcohol for decades, he displays behaviors seen commonly in alcoholism-induced dementia, such as stumbling over his words.  He has always behaved in this way at different times, but as his age has advanced, the effects of a lifetime of substance abuses worsen.

Women aren't responsible to be "less" so as not to threaten a man's image.  She's literally just standing there smiling brightly in a single moment, and being called a control freak / abuser for it.  Wow.

comment:
I don‚Äôt know if this is the right video to say this but here we go. Thank you for making this channel. I am an autistic woman, so I struggle to understand and interpret people‚Äôs intentions (I‚Äôve always been gullible) and interactions with others in general can be difficult for me. This makes me quite vulnerable for obvious reasons. 

Since finding your videos, I‚Äôve learned so much about body language in neurotypical people. Your videos have really helped me read others and sniff out bad intentions before I get hurt.

I do have to wonder what it would be like for you to analyze the body language of autistic people. It is generally different than expected and sometimes gives off the wrong impression to neurotypical people.

For example, I have a hard time looking people in the eye and get distracted by my surroundings a lot which, to typical people, looks like I‚Äôm nervous or lying. Another example is that I don‚Äôt gesture with my hands much and I have a flat affect (neutral facial expression and monotonous voice), especially when I‚Äôm tired.

I‚Äôm kind of curious about what you would think of the body language of people with communication disorders.

comment: I have never been through domestic violence, but as someone who has been through intense and life altering trauma, I can say that sometimes I use odd emotional reactions when recalling or talking about it because I try to keep the floodgates closed. author: Tanya

comment: Poor guy... that woman is 100% a malignant Narcissist. She will have swept him off his feet with a false facade, then secured control over him by crushing his sense of self-worth and confidence. These people are masters at finding the wounds and then tearing them further open under the guise of ''being worried'' or ''out of love''. They also will gaslight the victim into oblivion, both further crushing their sense of self-worth and also making it easier for the abuser to control the narratives. It might also explain why Depp seemed so uncertain and hesitant. It can take years for a severely gaslight person to fully recover their self-confidence and to trust in their memory and instinct again. Gas-lighting does horrible damage to people's minds!

comment:
That clip at the end with Johnny and Amber really made it obvious that he was afraid of her! And the way she looked at him the whole time really showed she was the dominant one. Something that I noticed about Johnny in each clip was that in the first one he was sober and really considered his words to make sure he got it right, and in the one with Amber, he seemed like he wasn't sober, he was slurring his speech and he was far less aware of what he was saying. He definitely wasn't in a healthy and coherent state, while Amber was clearly sober and she looked down on him. 

Johnny little smirk to me seemed like he was trying to find humour or he was disgusted by the reality of the situation, I've caught myself doing it during councilling sessions too, and it's really a way of acknowledging the incident, as of to finally say "Yes, this happened." Maybe he sees the rediculousness of the situation or just how horrible it was. It's also sometimes a feeling of overcoming a situation and feeling like it's in the past, but still very real, like it's an emotional moment to realise a detail or that it happened, and it's almost intriguing to compare the feelings of then and now, or the contrast between the situation then and the situation now.

I can't get over his reactions when he looked up at her. And how she made sure he made eye contact even when he was trying not to. Man oh man.

comment:
I‚Äôm an attorney and I‚Äôve never seen anyone actually eat during a deposition.

Had I been the one questioning her, I would have said ‚Äúlet‚Äôs take a 5 minute break so your client can finish her meal because the eating and speaking simultaneously is rude and disrespectful to both me and the court reporter as it‚Äôs difficult to to hear what Ms Heard is saying with a mouth full of food.‚Äù

Though, from what I understand, it was difficult to get Amber to sit for the deposition and she and her counsel put up all kinds of stumbling blocks before they sat at the deposition table.  I‚Äôm sure Johnny‚Äôs attorney was looking forward to  questioning Amber and getting Amber to contradict herself, so she may have been willing to tolerate a bit of chewing.

It‚Äôs normal to have water, coffee, soft drinks, gum, mints, even hard candy is ok as long as the person keeps it under control and isn‚Äôt crunching and/or slurping. 
But this!  She may as well took out a fork and knife and put a napkin on her lap!
Judges get really upset at this kind of sh*t because it‚Äôs viewed as a deliberate attempt to thwart the process as well as disrespectful to the court reporter.

comment: As someone who studied the psychology of personal relations (relationship psychology) which includes understanding domestic abuse, it's very disturbing how we always take sides. One thing to note is that many abusive relationships exist where BOTH take part in the abuse. The "you hit me, I hit you back harder" mentality, not for self-defense but for pure vengeance and exerting aggression. I'm not necessarily saying that's exactly what's going on here, but for almost no one to be considering it as a possibility is pretty mind-boggling.

comment:
Why YouTube removes my comment? Is there some kind of censorship? At least i should have been informed why the comment is removed by the administrator.
From what I can see I can tell that Heard thinks that she is a better actress than she really is. Her conduct shows that she has narcissistic and antisocial personality traits. She can also exhibit violent conduct and other behavioral disorders, which she thinks are completely okay because she thinks it is always someone else's fault. There are definitely signs of disinhibition in her conduct which come across as a lack of respect towards the court as well as entitlement, which are traits often found in antisocial individuals. I believe that she is driven by the economic profit (which is usually the incentive of these personality disorders). She believes she is better than the rest of the people around her and she can manipulate everyone into thinking what she wants them to think. An that she is more clever than the others so that her reputation will not only remain intact, but also be even more loveable as a victim. And that Depp has a flawed control over reality due to his problems and more to lose due to exposure (that he will fear exposure) and therefore that it is not her fault, but he will let her get what she wants as a result of his cowardice.(that's what she believes) Depp exhibits psychomotor retardation which is a symptom. It can be consistent with a variety of different things involving major depressive disorder commorbid with substance abuse.

comment: Just going to throw it out there that I don‚Äôt believe Amber- I‚Äôm not trying to defend her. However, in regard to the way the material was analyzed in the video, I don‚Äôt believe it was unbiased. In the last clip, there were inferences made about her being a ‚Äúgood partner‚Äù which cannot be generalized off one clip where her hair is mostly covering her face, making it difficult to point out condescension. In the two deposition clips, there was no mention of the time gap of around 2 years nor was there any mention of how off screen activity can influence a person‚Äôs verbal and nonverbal language. I am in no way defending the actions of either Johnny Depp or Amber Heard. I am simply pointing out the discrepancies between the analysis for these two people.

One other thing that really bugs me about watching the deposition, is her turning her head strongly to one side, then turning it to the other. Reminds me of a dog who's trying to understand something or is confused about what they are seeing/hearing. With that said, I'm new to your channel, and I love what you do. Reminds me of that tv show Lie To Me, which I enjoyed as well! comment:
6:30 she is not misaligned.  At all.  Let me fill in the unspoken parts.

q: Did you ever commit ever commit an act of domestic violence against Johnny Depp;
Amber: *pauses*
q: Do you understand the question?
Amber: *nods* (I do understand the question and my answer is ) "No"
q: "No?" (you don't understand the question?)
Amber: *realizes the confusion* (I need to be clearer, so let me say) "Yes, I do understand what you are asking"

So yeah.  Not the misalignment that you claim.  It is just that that the questioner asked 2 questions, and the situation got a little confusing at that point.  You are billing yourself as a body language analyst, but you can't seem to put together even a rudimentary understanding of what is happening.  Ugh.  I'm done.

author: Disaster Struck

comment:
I worked in a DV shelter for a few years, and the responses were pretty accurate with what I saw at the shelter and when we'd go to the court for hearings and the abuser was present. When someone asks a "yes or no" question, and it takes you 20 minutes to tell a story that neglects to answer the question...you're hiding something. I was the children's specialist/music therapist, and when children did that, it was often to protect a parent. They had fear that something bad would happen to them or to their parent. When the adults did that, it was to protect themselves from something. I think the assessment of Heard being an abuser is pretty accurate given her affect, and Depp appears to be similar to many in the shelter I saw and assisted.
Also, who allows food in a hearing?! Unless it's during a break, all we could have present was water, if that!

author: GT Godbear

comment: I work professionally as a domestic violence victim advocate, and I am also a survivor of domestic violence. I question whether reading micro-expressions can be accurately applied to a domestic violence victim because all abusive relationships include psychological abuse, making the victim question their memory and experience of the relationship. This could cause them to be unsure of their own responses. I have accompanied many victims to court and they commonly have things with them to self-sooth because of the inner anxiety that they feel. I actually give them items to fidget with to help them in court. I also would caution anyone against saying things such as ‚Äùa real victim would not behave this way‚Äù or ‚Äùif she was a victim, she would behave this way‚Äù. Victims respond to trauma in very different ways. Some respond in what is seen as a ‚Äùtypical‚Äù way - frightened, teary, etc. Many victims respond to trauma by emotionally distancing themselves. I have no idea whether Amber Heard is the victim or perpetrator, this is just my input of whether a primary aggressor can be determined based on micro-expressions.

I did a deposition for a medical malpractice lawsuit. I got to watch all the defendants depositions (mine wasn‚Äôt recorded). Now, I knew the doctors were lying and their body language clearly showed it too. She moves and speaks in the same ways they were. The main doctor involved also was drinking/eating constantly during the process. Aggravating.

It‚Äôs also though why my attorney said they like to record depositions. They can show all of this to a jury. If a jury sees her acting so irritated that she has to be there and messing up constantly on her words, they‚Äôll pick up on it. It works so much better than just reading off the deposition to a group of people.

comment:
I get so annoyed when ppl dont get WHY ppl who've been through trauma like abusive relationship, (and I'm stating this from my earlier work as counselor, being a kid of violent mom who hit my dad and me being in a violent relationship for 7 of the 11years abusive and bit after, anywho, I've been lucky and had lots of counselling AND motivational speaker too, so I've dealt with it in many ways, especially as an observant) here you see 2 ppl who are far from having dealt with it 
But as a victim( I hate that word) the dupid delight smile can be 3 things!
 1. Coping mechanism. You make jokes, smile even laugh oddly in very inappropriate situation or when you're retelling about the hurtful situation! 
For if you are serious and sad everytime you have to explain certain aspect/situation of your life that was awful, you'd be afraid you'll but you're scared that IF you do get sad ,perhaps cry, the pain would never go away, so its easier to cope almost in non serious way! (Most men or women who's masculine (specially in front of other/s ) The body feel the pain again and by joking, laughing or smiling, it releases sometimes soothing feeling in your body like taking a puff from a smoke!  It's hard to explain but I've seen it on numerous victims and I still do it today(the  was the masculine type,but have become a crybaby, but rarely when I gotta explain about that part of my life, I think I'm still afraid the pain will reappear and never dissapear (I know the pain have already become bearable,and I'm.I'm.even mad at my ex or myself anymore(only the part where the kids were inflicted) and its 14 year ago I left the twat!And I've heard men say the same and handful women, but it depends on stages of the healing) IF the healing have started,here you see it's still early, but amber havent acknowledge or taken any responsibility, will she ever???
2. I call it "redemption smile" (I dont think that was the case here, maybe a fraction?) But when its OVER, you're free so much free that you're able to talk about it and 
A.the abuser has been caught 
B. You know the abuser IS getting caught cuz of the stuff you're saying at that moment, the smile appear , kind of "finally, karma or eat that jerk" and a natural smirk shows,for its finally your time to talk after being silenced!
3. Personality (you say it yourself in lots of other vids) that depends on the person, often you only have few seconds/minutes to figure "main expressions" out!
I'm not a pro, but by having observed my parents, later on I had my reason to be better at reading ppl as counselor and later as drugdealer (sometimes you have few seconds to see if they're gonna screw you or is it genuine etc) you learn to read ppl.
Having a violent parent or partner you learn to read body language early on,walking on eggshells to see the state the abuser are at?!!

SO my conclusion on this infamous dupid delight or what else ppl call it, for Johnny it's one of his trades,personality, the prankster,funny gu√Ω, mixed with coping and HaHa ,I'm gonna get'ya so I'd say all 3 above! Which is very common to see, women often are more soft!

I've learned it's much harder to see when its male victims. 
My guess is most men are taught to be masculine, no crying,no emotions etc, so the natural way of coping has a huge wall cuz while he NEED in this case to show he's a victim, he have the funnyman personality but also "men do no crying upbringining"
For me it's obvious that's what he's doing. 
But the balance has changed but many  peoples emotions havent learned to live like this, and that's ppl, especially men who are brought up the oldfasioned way.
Today you almost let your son play with dolls and wear skirts, so they're are more easily to show real feelings.
But if you look at Johnny's Italian background, age, etc, it's obvious HE have to hide & be funny while sharing something very hurtful.

I feel often many YouTube body language reader forget some important factors that actually also can and often changes the body language, not only the sexes and wether you're most masculine vs feminine but CULTURE! 

Now the ppl most youtubers are studying are American! So that's fine.
But I've learned from early age it really also depends on country,class,religion too.
I'm most familiar with culture cus I was born and raised in Japan (we don't talk or show our feeling, we don't tough each other, imagine and pride is VERY important and older you are,more respect you show,get,gain)
While here in Denmark, omg it's the opposite!( let's sit in a circle, sing a song,play guitar,paint, we hug and hold hands even kiss and we SHARE ALL our feeling to everyone, then we are healthy, respect is something I'm not sure how you gain, old ppl are look down on) 
So to say these 2 cultures have same body language is impossible! 
1 have been taught with breastmilk not to show anything, the other cry as high and let it  ALL out) tho it's fun to see for I know many mixed marriages and confused kids (me,lmfao) 
Yes, there are many HUMAN trades,but many are removed or added!
I'm taught to be very square but after living here for so many years I'm become round, I don't fit in,both cultures have hard time reading me, even if i make a joke i see some are afraid to laugh cuz they're not sure iF I'm serious or not. I know i can be monotone when I need too, and it also depends where and who im with what part of me I show, and I'm VERY aware what I portray, and have been very manipulative!
And I guess its same issue with classes, religion and colour/culture for it has nothing to do with amount of melanin, it's how you're raised and been exposed too.

So its so hard (unless if you have studied this like you, and I'm self taught cuz I had too in order to survive)

ButIi think many readers are generalizing and forget other factors! 
And also wether you're left/righthand can change the "norm" or are you logic person.or artistic person(they often gave bigger hand gestures,dont know why, just observed it)!

Most importantly to be a great reader LIFE EXPERIENCE ! Without that, you cant use the tools, then it's cold reading like Caputo lady! 
So I do sometime laugh when I see a student in psychology,still in university using the body language ABZ but you obviously hear they havent lived.
In order to read ppl you have had to had a life and the brain should be fully developed ! 
But gotta admit some do surprise me and they're a natural, and I can almost guess why.

Back to Johnny;

I'm a woman, I can't imagine how it is for men to.be the victim. 
I had zero respect for my huge danish dad who got beaten by a tiny japanese woman & I waited many years for him to one day snap, but nope, he was like Johnny. (I have the biggest respect today, my dad,Johnny were more MAN than most men are! ) 

It really takes balls, self control,respect for you and others to not hit back as a man who's bigger!

That's why this particular relationship is for me so transparent and I'm angry that Amber Poo have made it hard on women/victims in the future 
But I think and hope by a masculine man as johnny both men and women respect and look upto openly stating,yes this tiny turd chopped my finger, butchered me and beat me! That MORE men are inclined to step forward.
I hope this will change the way we look at men!

Damn,sry for the book I wrote he its 06.16 I gotta get up soon

But I enjoyed your videos and looking forward to watch many many more

Great channel XoXo  MM

comment: About 19:40 and the story about Johnny almost pushing her sister off a flight of stairs. The story is actually the other way around (as everything she claims). comment:
At the beginning of Amber‚Äôs clip, regarding the nod: She is nodding her head in affirmation that she understands the question, then says verbally, ‚ÄúNo‚Äù, that she did not engage in domestic abuse. The responses aren‚Äôt contrasting each other, they‚Äôre answers to two separate questions. 
Stated another way: Lawyer One asks Amber if she has engaged in domestic violence. Her lawyer objects. Lawyer One asks her if she understands the question. Amber begins nodding that yes, she understands the question, then says ‚ÄúNo‚Äù (that she has not engaged in domestic violence) as a response to that question. 
A minor detail, but maybe not if you‚Äôre using it as a predictor that she‚Äôs going to be extremely deceptive with what follows. I‚Äôm in no way defending her (in fact, I believe she‚Äôs guilty as sin of perpetrating domestic violence), just pointing out that it was interpreted incorrectly. 
‚òÆÔ∏èüíú‚òÆÔ∏è

comment: When you‚Äôre reading, how do you look out for signs of neurodivergency (autism, ADHD, trauma, etc?). To me it seems like Amber exhibits some ADHD symptoms at her baseline, such as the scanning the room while engaged, and the way she expressed her artistic inclination in relation to her family both could be because of ADHD. In the clip of her deposition things such as her boredom and her inability to recall the exact details of events could also be perceived as symptoms. A red carpet setting would also be an added layer of overwhelming for people who are not neurotypical as well because of the bombardment of stimuli, this could explain both of their behaviors‚Äô in this setting. When in a calm environment they could interact very differently. I still think your reading supports that she is likely an abuser but it‚Äôs also interesting to me that you so readily note Depp‚Äôs ability to recall and recite his side as an indicator he is being truthful when he is such a gifted actor. In Shane‚Äôs reading you often cited him being an ‚Äúactor‚Äù as something to consider but don‚Äôt mention it in regards to Johnny... smells a bit like bias to me. I would be extremely interested to hear if and how you are accounting for the possibility of neurodivergence in your readings.

author: Tiffany

comment:
Im sorry, i don't know much about this case and i've loved every single video i watched of you, but there's something i find very troubling about this one. As far as i understand, there Is no specific way a victim of abuse would respond to this type of questions. And i find troubling that one of the main resons she Is found to be not believable is because she Is not reacting like people asume victims of abuse should act... She's not crying, she's not super invested in the questioning... But if this Is a recolection of abuse she suffered for a really long time and probably has had to talk about many many times to prepare for the depositions and etc, it's not wild to think she would not react as emotionally to it anymore, if she ever did, which again, she wouldn't have to, just to prove it's true. 
Another thing Is that it's extremely common for recollections of abuse to be incongruent when retold. What Is not very common at all, is for a woman to lie about being abused. It's extremely rare. 
To be honest, it's not that i believe her and i'm trying to jump in her defense, because i truly don't know what happened. It's just that every reason you've given in the video i could not find compelling in the slightless. 
Another thing Is that there's no mention to both of them being actors which you've Said before, could make it a Lot harder to read. He Is taken as genuine without mentioning that very important factor.
I really dislike leaving negative comments but when it comes to important subjects like this i just feel it's necessary.
Perhaps you did have in consideration all the things i said about victims of abuse reacting differently, and the studies that have been done surrounding the topic, (un fact i would asume you do because you seem to be a very well educsted person) but non of that comes across in the video, and it worries me. 
Because it normalizes the idea that a victim has to be bawling her eyes out in order to be truthfull, and that v√≠ctims lying about abuse it's not an extremely rare thing. 
I hope you get to read this comment and take it to heart to be More careful in how you handle topics of abuse. 
I truly love your videos and Will continue watching them hoping that something like this doesn't repit itself. (Also sorry if i have any errors, english Is not my first language)
author: Valentina Cavalotti Velasco

author: Meagan

comment:
Hi, love your channel, but I have some questions. I think some crucial things might have been left out in the analysis of Amber's video, one being that the case was about Johnny, not her. She wasn't on trial, so why would she be nervous? If she looked bored and didn't want to be there.. probably because they wanted to (theoretically) twist her story and victim blame her. If he did abuse her than she would probably feel real contempt for Johnny's lawyers as their whole goal would be to call her a liar when she is telling the truth? I'm not saying one way or the other, but I'm just not sure all the facts were considered when analysing her deposition? If she IS a victim and their whole purpose was to discredit her, she would hate them. Or maybe they had badgered her over and over again. Or even consider the hypothetical situation where you are an abuse victim, but a lawyer brings up one of the only times you defended yourself, that would make you so mad and upset, maybe even cause you to trip up on your words? I haven't seen a video where Johny is questioned on how many times he has abused her? Is there one? If so I'd be interested to see an analysis of that, where he denies abusing her and we can look at his nonverbal to see if that is the truth. Because, let's say she did hit him those few times she was questioned about and she was lying, that doesn't automatically mean he didn't abuse her? So how can we have a clear picture?
Furthermore, with the interpretation of the footage of them together, Johnny is obviously drunk. Maybe he was looking at her for guidance because he was a mess? And perhaps she was upset with him for something? I think its quite a big call to say that proves she abused him. Say Johnny had recently abused her, what's to say he didn't act submissive after because he felt shame or guilt? These are genuine questions. I'm just not understanding why certain possibilities don't play into the analysis, but other things do (in favour of Johnny).
Perhaps a longer video would be cool to see, maybe you had already considered these things but didn't have time to say? It's just, I don't mean this in a bad way, but this analysis seemed more emotional than others (i.e. more anger and frustration directed towards Amber than other videos I have seen) and I'm wondering if this could have swayed the analysis at all? I ask these questions with all the love and respect! :) Thanks for sharing your videos :)

Her lawyer needs to learn the difference between 'You were already asked that question' and 'You already answered that question'. By contrast, Johnny is known to be a very shy, quiet person but speaks clearly about relevant things and makes eye contact. I've seen him do the smirk quite a lot in interviews. comment: 5:38 that's not necessarily true...speaking as someone who has so much mental stimulation at any given time, I tend to focus my eyes on various stationary things around the room sometimes when I'm in deep conversations with people because it actually helps me hone in on what they're saying, and it helps me form my response thoughtfully as well...I think very hard before speaking. I don't know how to describe that need to someone who doesn't know what that's like lol but it's a thing - and certainly doesn't indicate that I'm disinterested in the subject matter or the other person üòä just sayin. I do very much value and enjoy deep eye contact as well though, so I'm not darting my eyes around the room for the entirety of the conversation lol I think the other person would find that rude of me. I know there's no one-size-fits-all rule for this type of thing, but I thought it was important to point that out. Great video as always!!

comment:
I couldn't eat if I was her because I would have been too tense to eat. She is eating the food to give her more time or it's because she wanted to. Also, I don't know about Amber but I am very self conscious when eating in front of other people I don't know. It makes me nervous to eat in front of new people all casually like that.

11:23
"I was trying to escape, from a room. Uh, where Johnny was attacking me, and in order to escape, I was trying to, get to on the other side of the door. Attempting to close the door, and he was attempting to get in, despite my attempts to try and escape an assault."
In this saying there is one thing that stood out for me, the ending part, where she used the word escape. If she was a victim I don't think she would have used that word as many times as she did, she would have said "despite my desperate attempts to try and stop him" or "despite my attempts to try and get away from him."
Also she used the word attempt 3x in that short few second clip.
If you are remembering a memory/having a flashback, it is vivid. The image takes you there, almost like you relive the moment. And Amber? She doesn't look or sound like she is reliving something that was terrifying for her.

12:32
"Yes, as he was trying to get into the door, uh, into the room, I was trying to escape in. He, pushed the door into me, and I was trying to hit him (waves arms), by getting out, getting him out of the door, to stay in the room."
There is a confession in this clip, I believe. Not 100% sure, but by her struggles to retell the story of what she just said a minute before, she sounded like she almost confessed to hitting Johnny, but then said it was because she was trying to close the door.
I also can see she is waving her arms in almost like a "No! I mean, sh*t!" type of way because she realized what she was saying then backtracked to the door. (Her story)

13:35
"I think in that recording I made it very clear that I was sorry that the door hit him while he was trying to get into the room, I was, escaping (closes eyes) or attempting to escape into. (Puts hand on arm casually and looks around in boredom)

20:12
Please note, I could be wrong about this, but when she talks about the incident with her sister, something tells me she was not referring to her sister but to herself.
She is telling the story how she saw it, getting defensive by how she saw it, saying she was gonna protect her sister no matter what, saying that Johnny was gonna get violent, but I think she was referring to herself, like in third person. That there was no sister there, just her, and she saw herself as the little girl.
(I.e. The story of her sister is made up, she is referring to herself as the little girl/in third person. I think it's made up)

22:24
Johnny is telling the truth/a memory, at least for the vodka bottle story because he is reliving the moment and is very open and expressive about it. He is telling that story like a memory because there is no hesitation and a lot of subtle details. "My hand was resting on the marble"

comment: I think I may understand what Johnny‚Äôs little smirks were when asked to recount the abuse he endured. I think it‚Äôs a mix of feeling shame and being anxious. author: Carmen Sparkle

comment:
A comment which you can take or leave, but comes from my perspective of being a litigation lawyer.  I think its important to keep in mind that court rooms are very stilted and artificial environments, very different to being interviewed or chatting casually. Someone's baseline in a court room situation I'd wager is different to their baseline in other places. I have seen clients/witnesses I know to be truthful/decent people give weird and illogical answers on the stand. There can be innocent explanations for this - being nervous, annoyed to be involved in the court process, making an honest mistake (its rare for people to have perfect recall), scared to say something 'wrong' so they end up confusing themselves. Some witnesses may try to run away with irrelevant facts, because what they see as important may differ from what is actually important (eg focus on something which is inconsequential but was irritating to them at the time). 

I didn't necessarily agree that Amber's disjointed stories were inherently an indicated she was lying. I generally understood the story she was trying to tell, even if she did not express herself well explaining them. Some witnesses really are like that on the stand, but if you ask them the same question back in the office they will answer much more cohesively. The way some of the questions were framed did not necessarily encourage a cohesive answer because they did not necessarily encourage a chronological recount of events. Her answers to some questions suggested that her lawyer either didn't prepare her well for the deposition or she ignored their advice. 

To me the strangest thing was that she ate through the deposition -  which I would basically ban a client from doing unless they were a diabetic or something. I agree there was some overacting around the eating, which felt a little like play acting.  I did generally think Johnny came across as the much better witness, but being a good witness does not necessarily mean someone is telling the truth, particularly when the someones are professional actors.
